docs.title: Michigan Senate Bill Clerk Training Course
docs.text:
Welcome! This comprehensive training course prepares you for the Michigan Senate Bill Clerk position through 20 hours of self-paced study covering legislative processes, procedures, and terminology.

Course Duration

20 hours over 2 weeks of self-paced study

What You'll Learn

Real-time coding of legislative actions during Senate sessions, complete bill lifecycle tracking, and all Michigan-specific procedures and terminology

Ready to Begin?

Start with Module 1: Foundations

docs.title: 🎯 What You'll Learn
docs.text:
This course provides everything you need to understand Michigan's legislative process and excel as a Bill Clerk:

  • Michigan government structure and Senate operations
  • Complete bill lifecycle from introduction to enactment
  • Committee processes and all 17 standing committees
  • Floor procedures (General Orders and Third Reading)
  • Comprehensive legislative terminology
  • Senate-House interaction and conference committees
  • Real-time coding of legislative actions
  • Interview preparation strategies

docs.title: 👨‍💼 What Bill Clerks Do
docs.text:
Bill Clerks are essential to Michigan Senate operations. Your role would include:

  • Code legislative actions in real-time during Senate sessions
  • Track bills through committee, floor debates, and votes
  • Record amendments, motions, and vote counts accurately
  • Monitor bills moving between Senate and House
  • Maintain precise records for the official Senate Journal
  • Support Senate leadership and operations

Key Skills Required: - Attention to detail and accuracy - Ability to work quickly under pressure - Strong listening and comprehension skills - Knowledge of legislative procedures and terminology - Professional communication - Focus during long sessions

docs.title: Module 6: Senate-House Interaction

docs.title: Important Rules:
docs.text:

  • Identical versions: Both chambers must pass same text before going to Governor
  • Lt. Governor presides as President of Senate
  • No filibuster in Michigan Senate (unlike U.S. Senate)

docs.text: ✅ Set aside dedicated study time - treat this like a class ✅ Take notes - writing reinforces learning ✅ Complete all quizzes - test your understanding ✅ Practice coding out loud - simulate real-time work ✅ Ask questions - no question is too basic ✅ Review regularly - repetition builds retention ✅ Use flashcards - for terminology and numbers ✅ Watch archived sessions - see procedures in action

docs.text: ✅ Know the basics cold - 38, 110, 17, 20, 26, 5 ✅ Explain bill lifecycle clearly - practice out loud ✅ Emphasize your teaching background - it's an asset! ✅ Show genuine interest - passion for public service ✅ Ask thoughtful questions - about role and organization ✅ Be honest - say "I don't know but I'll find out" if needed ✅ Follow up - thank-you email within 24 hours

docs.title: On the Job:
docs.text: ✅ Listen carefully - accuracy starts with hearing correctly ✅ Ask when unsure - never guess on critical information ✅ Double-check numbers - vote counts must be precise ✅ Stay focused - sessions can be long ✅ Learn from experienced clerks - observe and ask questions ✅ Review the Journal - see how actions are officially recorded ✅ Keep reference materials handy - Quick Reference Guide is your friend

docs.title: 🌟 Why This Training Matters
docs.text:
As a Bill Clerk, you're not just recording information - you're:

  • Creating the official legislative record that courts may reference
  • Supporting democracy by ensuring accurate documentation
  • Enabling transparency through precise public records
  • Assisting legislators in their constitutional duties
  • Contributing to Michigan's governance

Your accuracy and attention to detail directly impact: - Legislative history and intent - Legal interpretation of statutes - Public access to government proceedings - Institutional memory of the Senate

This is important work. You're preparing to be excellent at it. 💪

docs.title: The Three Branches of Michigan Government
docs.text: Michigan, like the federal government, operates under a system of separated powers with three co-equal branches:

docs.title: 1. Executive Branch
docs.text:
• Leader: Governor of Michigan
  • Role: Enforces and implements laws passed by the Legislature
  • Key Powers:
  • Signs or vetoes legislation
  • Prepares state budget
  • Appoints department heads and judges
  • Commander-in-chief of state military forces

docs.title: 2. Legislative Branch
docs.text:
• Leader: Lt. Governor (as President of Senate) and Speaker of the House
  • Role: Creates, debates, and passes laws for the state
  • Composition: Bicameral (two chambers)
  • Senate: 38 members serving 4-year terms
  • House of Representatives: 110 members serving 2-year terms
  • Key Powers:
  • Passes state laws
  • Approves state budget
  • Can override gubernatorial vetoes (2/3 vote)
  • Confirms certain gubernatorial appointments

docs.title: 3. Judicial Branch
docs.text:
• Leader: Chief Justice of the Michigan Supreme Court
  • Role: Interprets laws and administers justice
  • Structure: Supreme Court (7 justices), Court of Appeals, Circuit Courts, District Courts
  • Key Powers:
  • Reviews constitutionality of laws
  • Hears appeals from lower courts
  • Final interpreter of Michigan law

docs.title: Michigan's Bicameral Legislature
docs.text: Michigan's Legislature consists of two chambers, making it bicameral:

docs.title: Michigan Senate
docs.text:
• 38 Senators representing districts across Michigan
  • 4-year terms (half elected every 2 years)
  • Term limits: Maximum of 2 full terms (8 years total in combined legislative service under new rules)
  • Districts: Each senator represents approximately 260,000 constituents

docs.title: Michigan House of Representatives
docs.text:
• 110 Representatives representing smaller districts
  • 2-year terms (all seats up for election every 2 years)
  • Term limits: Same combined 8-year limit across both chambers
  • Districts: Each representative represents approximately 90,000 constituents

docs.title: Why Bicameral?
docs.text:
• Checks and balances: Each chamber reviews the other's work
  • Different perspectives: Senators have longer terms (more stability), Representatives are more frequently accountable to voters
  • Thorough review: Bills must pass both chambers in identical form
  • Historical tradition: Modeled after U.S. Congress

docs.title: Michigan Senate Leadership Positions
docs.text: Understanding the leadership structure is essential for Bill Clerks, as these positions control the flow of legislation:

docs.title: President of the Senate
docs.text:
• Position held by: Lieutenant Governor of Michigan
  • Role: Presides over Senate sessions, maintains order, recognizes speakers
  • Voting: Only votes to break ties (rare)
  • Powers: While presiding over sessions, the President's only substantive power is casting tie-breaking votes

docs.title: President Pro Tempore (Pro Tem)
docs.text:
• Elected by: Senate membership
  • Role: Presides when Lt. Governor is absent
  • Typically: Senior member of majority party

docs.title: Majority Leader
docs.text:
• Elected by: Majority party caucus
  • Role: Chief strategist and spokesperson for majority party
  • Powers:
  • Sets legislative agenda
  • Controls floor schedule
  • Determines which bills come up for votes
  • Primary authority for committee referrals

For Your Job

The Majority Leader is the most powerful position in day-to-day Senate operations. Pay close attention to their actions and statements.

docs.title: Minority Leader
docs.text:
• Elected by: Minority party caucus
  • Role: Lead spokesperson for minority party
  • Powers:
  • Represents minority party interests
  • Negotiates with Majority Leader
  • Organizes opposition or support for bills

docs.title: Majority Floor Leader
docs.text:
• Elected by: Majority Caucus
  • Responsibilities: Works with minority floor leader on expected activities on the floor, makes/disputes point of orders, executes the days' activities, works closely with Majority Leader

docs.title: Minority Floor Leader
docs.text:
• Elected by: Minority Caucus
  • Role: Day-to-day point person for daily floor activity
  • Responsibilities: Works with majority floor leader on expected activities, executes any opposition activities, makes/disputes point of orders or rulings

docs.text:
• Role: Count votes, communicate party positions to caucus members
  • Critical during: Close votes and important legislation

docs.title: The 17 Michigan Senate Standing Committees (2025-2026)
docs.text: As a Bill Clerk, you need to know these committees because bills are referred to them by subject matter. Each committee has jurisdiction over specific policy areas:

docs.title: 1. Appropriations
docs.text:
• Jurisdiction: State budget, funding for all state operations
  • Special status: All bills with fiscal impact (spending) eventually go here
  • Most powerful committee: Controls state purse strings

docs.title: 2. Civil Rights, Judiciary, and Public Safety
docs.text: • Jurisdiction: Courts, criminal law, civil rights, prisons, law enforcement, sentencing

docs.title: 3. Economic and Community Development
docs.text: • Jurisdiction: Economic development, small business, tourism, community revitalization

docs.title: 4. Education
docs.text: • Jurisdiction: K-12 education, school funding, education policy, teacher certification

docs.title: 5. Elections and Ethics
docs.text: • Jurisdiction: Election law, campaign finance, legislative ethics, voter registration

docs.title: 6. Energy and Environment
docs.text: • Jurisdiction: Energy policy, utilities, environmental protection, climate issues

docs.title: 7. Finance, Insurance, and Consumer Protection
docs.text: • Jurisdiction: Banking, insurance, consumer protection, financial regulations

docs.title: 8. Government Operations
docs.text: • Jurisdiction: State government structure, civil service, administrative procedures

docs.title: 9. Health Policy
docs.text: • Jurisdiction: Healthcare, Medicaid, public health, health insurance, hospitals

docs.title: 10. Housing and Human Services
docs.text: • Jurisdiction: Housing policy, welfare programs, family services, child welfare

docs.title: 11. Labor
docs.text: • Jurisdiction: Employment law, workers' compensation, unemployment, unions, workplace safety

docs.title: 12. Local Government
docs.text: • Jurisdiction: County/city/township government, local taxation, municipal finance

docs.title: 13. Natural Resources and Agriculture
docs.text: • Jurisdiction: Farming, forestry, wildlife, state parks, Department of Natural Resources

docs.title: 14. Oversight
docs.text: • Jurisdiction: Investigates state agencies, government efficiency, waste/fraud

docs.title: 15. Regulatory Affairs
docs.text: • Jurisdiction: Professional licensing, occupational regulations, state regulations

docs.title: 16. Transportation and Infrastructure
docs.text: • Jurisdiction: Roads, bridges, public transit, transportation funding, infrastructure

docs.title: 17. Veterans and Emergency Services
docs.text: • Jurisdiction: Veterans' affairs, emergency management, homeland security, military affairs

docs.title: The Senate's Role in Lawmaking
docs.text: The Michigan Senate shares lawmaking responsibility with the House. Here's what the Senate does:

docs.title: Primary Functions:
docs.text:
1. Introduce legislation: Senators sponsor bills (designated with "SB" numbers)
  2. Review House bills: All House bills (HB) must pass Senate to become law
  3. Committee review: Committees hold hearings, amend, and vote on bills
  4. Floor debate: Full Senate debates and amends bills
  5. Vote on passage: Requires 20 votes (majority) to pass; 26 votes (2/3) for immediate effect
  6. Confirm appointments: Senate confirms certain gubernatorial appointments
  7. Budget approval: Must approve state budget (Appropriations Committee leads)

docs.title: Senate Advantages:
docs.text:
• Longer terms: 4 years allows more stability and less campaigning
  • Smaller size: 38 members can build deeper relationships, easier to reach consensus
  • Greater prestige: Often seen as "upper chamber"
  • Confirms appointments: House does not have this power

docs.title: What Senate Does NOT Do:
docs.text:
• Cannot pass laws alone: House must also pass identical bill
  • Cannot override Governor alone: Needs House for 2/3 override vote
  • Cannot tax without House: Revenue bills can start in either chamber, but both must agree

docs.title: Federal vs. State Differences
docs.text: While Michigan's system mirrors the federal government in many ways, there are important differences:

docs.title: Similarities:
docs.text:
• Three branches with separation of powers
  • Bicameral legislature
  • Governor signs/vetoes like President
  • Override veto with 2/3 vote
  • Committees review legislation
  • Both chambers must pass identical bills

docs.title: Key Differences:
docs.text: Feature U.S. Congress Michigan Legislature Size 100 Senators, 435 Representatives 38 Senators, 110 Representatives Senate Terms 6 years 4 years House Terms 2 years 2 years Senate President Vice President (rarely present) Lt. Governor (regularly presides) Term Limits None 8 years combined in Legislature Session Length Year-round Year-round, but more breaks Immediate Effect Not applicable (federal laws have set effective dates) Requires 2/3 vote; otherwise 90 days after session ends Subject Matter National/international issues, interstate commerce State issues only (education, roads, state taxes, etc.) Impeachment House impeaches, Senate tries House impeaches, Senate tries (same) Filibuster Senate allows unlimited debate Michigan Senate does NOT have filibuster Cloture 60 votes to end debate (Senate) Not applicable in Michigan

docs.title: State Sovereignty
docs.text:
• Michigan can only legislate on state matters
  • Cannot contradict federal law (Supremacy Clause)
  • Cannot regulate interstate commerce (federal power)
  • Examples of state powers: education, intrastate roads, state criminal law, professional licensing

docs.title: Why This Matters for Bill Clerks
docs.text:
As a Bill Clerk, you'll be tracking bills through this complex system in real-time. You need to know:

  • Which committee a bill is in (affects timeline and amendments)
  • Leadership positions (who controls the agenda)
  • Vote requirements (20 for passage, 26 for immediate effect)
  • How Senate interacts with House (bills must pass both)
  • Structure of government (provides context for legislation)

Your job is to accurately code what happens to each bill as the Senate acts on it. Understanding the foundation helps you anticipate what comes next and catch errors.

docs.title: Self-Check Quiz
docs.text:
Test your understanding of Michigan government foundations:

Question 1: How many members are in the Michigan Senate, and how long are their terms? **Answer:** 38 Senators serving 4-year terms. Approximately half are elected every 2 years. Question 2: Who presides over the Michigan Senate, and when do they vote? **Answer:** The Lieutenant Governor serves as President of the Senate. The Lt. Governor only votes to break tie votes. Question 3: Which Senate leadership position has the most day-to-day power over the legislative agenda? **Answer:** The Majority Leader controls the legislative agenda, determines which bills come up for votes, and Controls all committee referrals. Question 4: Name at least 5 of the 17 Michigan Senate standing committees. **Answer:** Any 5 of: Appropriations, Civil Rights/Judiciary/Public Safety, Economic and Community Development, Education, Elections and Ethics, Energy and Environment, Finance/Insurance/Consumer Protection, Government Operations, Health Policy, Housing and Human Services, Labor, Local Government, Natural Resources and Agriculture, Oversight, Regulatory Affairs, Transportation and Infrastructure, Veterans and Emergency Services. Question 5: What committee has special status and reviews all bills with fiscal impact? **Answer:** The Appropriations Committee reviews all bills with fiscal impact (that spend state money). Question 6: How many votes are needed for a bill to pass the Senate? **Answer:** 20 votes (a majority of the 38 members) are needed for passage. 26 votes (2/3 majority) are needed if the bill is to take immediate effect. Question 7: True or False: The Michigan Senate has a filibuster like the U.S. Senate. **Answer:** False. The Michigan Senate does not have unlimited debate/filibuster rules like the U.S. Senate. Question 8: What happens if the Senate passes a bill but the House does not? **Answer:** The bill does not become law. Both chambers must pass identical versions of a bill for it to be sent to the Governor. Question 9: What are the three branches of Michigan government? **Answer:** Executive (Governor), Legislative (Senate and House), and Judicial (Courts led by Supreme Court). Question 10: A bill about K-12 school funding would likely be referred to which committee first, and then which committee second? **Answer:** First to the Education Committee (subject matter), then to the Appropriations Committee (because it involves spending state money).

docs.title: Notes for Instructor Q&A
docs.text:
Common questions from trainees:

Q: Do I need to memorize all 17 committee names? A: Yes, eventually. Start with the "big ones": Appropriations, Judiciary, Education, Health Policy, Transportation. You'll learn the others through repetition.

Q: What if the Lt. Governor and Majority Leader are from different parties? A: This is rare but possible. The Lt. Governor presides but the Majority Leader still controls the agenda. The presiding officer has limited power compared to the Majority Leader.

Q: How do I know which committee a bill goes to? A: The bill's subject matter determines this. You'll learn to recognize patterns. When in doubt, listen for the announcement or check the Senate Journal. The leadership makes the final decision.

Q: What's the difference between "standing committees" and other committees? A: Standing committees are permanent and meet regularly. Michigan also has special committees (temporary, for specific purposes) and conference committees (to reconcile House-Senate differences). You'll mostly deal with standing committees.

docs.text: ✅ Michigan has three branches: Executive, Legislative, Judicial ✅ Legislature is bicameral: 38 Senate, 110 House ✅ Lt. Governor presides over Senate; Majority Leader has most power ✅ 17 standing committees handle different policy areas ✅ Senate and House must both pass identical bills ✅ Bill Clerks need to know structure to code actions accurately

By the end of this module, you will be able to:

  • Explain the three readings requirement and the five-day rule
  • Describe committee actions and their impact on bills
  • Understand General Orders (Committee of the Whole)
  • Identify voting requirements for passage and immediate effect

docs.title: Overview: From Idea to Law
docs.text:
Becoming a law in Michigan is deliberately difficult. The process includes multiple checkpoints, readings, and votes to ensure thorough review. Most bills do NOT become law. Understanding each stage helps Bill Clerks accurately track and code bill status.

!!! note "Key Numbers to Remember" - 3 readings required for each bill - 5 days bill must be available before final passage (five-day rule) - 20 votes needed for passage (majority of 38) - 26 votes needed for immediate effect (2/3 of 38) - 90 days after session adjournment: when laws take effect without immediate effect clause

docs.title: Stage 1: Introduction (First Reading)
docs.text:
What Happens:

  • A Senator sponsors a bill and files it with the Secretary of the Senate
  • Bill receives a number (SB 1, SB 2, etc., in order of introduction)
  • Bill is read by title (or just the bill number) on the Senate floor
  • This is the First Reading
  • Bill is printed and made available to legislators and public

Bill Clerk Action:

  • Code bill as "introduced"
  • Note the sponsor(s) and date
  • Record first reading

Example

"Senate Bill 143, sponsored by Senator Jones, a bill to amend the vehicle code regarding electric vehicles. First reading."

Note: Sometimes multiple bills are introduced in a batch with quick first readings.

docs.title: Stage 2: Committee Referral
docs.text:
What Happens:

  • Immediately after first reading, the bill is referred to a committee by Senate leadership (primarily the Majority Leader)
  • Referral is based on the bill's subject matter
  • Majority Leader Controls all committee referrals
  • Can be referred to multiple committees (first to one, then to another)

Bill Clerk Action:

  • Code which committee receives the bill
  • Note date of referral

Example: "Senate Bill 143 is referred to the Committee on Transportation and Infrastructure."

Special Case: Bills involving spending usually go to a policy committee first, then to Appropriations Committee.

docs.title: Stage 3: Committee Action
docs.text:
What Happens in Committee:

  • Chair decides whether to hold a hearing (not all bills get hearings)
  • Public hearings allow testimony from experts, citizens, lobbyists
  • Committee members question witnesses and debate bill
  • Committee may amend the bill (make changes)
  • Committee votes on whether to report bill back to full Senate

Possible Committee Actions:

  1. Reported with Recommendation "Do Pass"

  2. Committee approves bill as written

  3. Goes to General Orders (Committee of the Whole)

  4. Reported with Recommendation "Do Pass as Amended"

  5. Committee made changes and approves amended version

  6. Goes to General Orders

  7. Reported with Substitute (Committee Substitute)

  8. Committee rewrote significant portions

  9. Original bill replaced with substitute

  10. Goes to General Orders

  11. Referred to Another Committee

  12. Sent to different committee (e.g., policy committee sends to Appropriations)

  13. Common for bills with fiscal impact

  14. Postponed

  15. Delayed for future consideration

  16. May or may not come back

  17. No Action

  18. Committee never votes on bill
  19. Bill effectively dies in committee
  20. Most bills die this way

Bill Clerk Action:

  • Code committee action accurately
  • Note any amendments or substitutes
  • Record date of committee report

Example: "The Committee on Transportation and Infrastructure reports Senate Bill 143 with recommendation 'do pass as amended.'"

Timeline Note: Committees meet on their own schedule. A bill can sit in committee for weeks, months, or forever.

docs.title: Stage 4: General Orders (Committee of the Whole) - Second Reading
docs.text:
What is General Orders?

  • "Committee of the Whole" means the entire Senate acts as one big committee
  • Less formal than Third Reading
  • This is where most debate and amendments happen
  • Senate can accept committee amendments, add new amendments, or reject amendments
  • Sometimes called "Second Reading"

What Happens:

  • Bill is placed on General Orders calendar
  • Sponsor explains bill to full Senate
  • Senators debate and offer floor amendments
  • Amendments are voted on (often by voice vote)
  • Senate votes to advance bill to Third Reading (or not)

Bill Clerk Action:

  • Code bill as "on General Orders"
  • Record all amendments offered and their outcomes (adopted/defeated)
  • Note when bill advances to Third Reading

Key Point: Bills can be amended heavily during General Orders. This is the flexible stage.

Example: "Senate Bill 143 is on General Orders. Senator Smith offers Floor Amendment 1. Amendment adopted. Bill advanced to Third Reading."

docs.title: Stage 5: Five-Day Rule ⏰
docs.text:
Critical Requirement

After a bill is placed on Third Reading calendar, it must be available in its final form for at least 5 calendar days before the Senate can take a final vote.

Purpose:

  • Gives legislators time to read final version
  • Allows public to see what will be voted on
  • Prevents surprise legislation

How It Works:

  • Count 5 full calendar days (not session days)
  • Includes weekends and holidays
  • Bill placed on Third Reading Monday → eligible for final vote Saturday
  • Bill placed on Third Reading Friday → eligible for final vote Wednesday

Exceptions:

  • Can be waived by 2/3 vote of Senate (rare)
  • Emergency situations (extremely rare)

Bill Clerk Action:

  • Track when bill placed on Third Reading
  • Calculate earliest date for final vote
  • Flag if bill is voted on too early (procedural error)

Common Mistake

Counting 5 session days instead of 5 calendar days. Always count calendar days!

docs.title: Stage 6: Third Reading and Final Passage 🗳️
docs.text:
What Happens:

  • This is the final, formal vote on the bill
  • Bill is read by title (Third Reading)
  • Limited debate (no amendments allowed without special consent)
  • Roll call vote taken
  • Each Senator's vote is recorded publicly

Voting Requirements:

For Passage:

  • 20 votes (majority of 38) required
  • If bill receives 20+ votes: PASSED
  • If bill receives fewer than 20 votes: DEFEATED

For Immediate Effect:

  • If bill is to take effect immediately upon signing (not waiting 90 days)
  • Requires 26 votes (2/3 of 38)
  • Separate vote after passage vote
  • Requires recorded roll call

Bill Clerk Action:

  • Code Third Reading
  • Record vote count (Yeas, Nays, Excused, Not Voting)
  • Note if bill passed or defeated
  • Record immediate effect vote separately if applicable

Example: "Third Reading of Senate Bill 143. The question being on passage of the bill. The bill passed, Yeas 32, Nays 6. Immediate effect? Yeas 28, Nays 10. Immediate effect granted."

Result: Bill passed and will take effect immediately when Governor signs.

docs.title: Stage 7: Other Chamber (House of Representatives)
docs.text:
What Happens:

  • Passed Senate bill goes to House
  • House goes through same process: first reading, committee referral, committee action, General Orders, Third Reading
  • House may pass bill as is, amend it, or defeat it

Three Possible Outcomes:

  1. House Passes Bill as Sent from Senate

  2. Identical version passed

  3. Bill goes to Governor

  4. No further Senate action needed

  5. House Passes Bill with Amendments

  6. House changed the bill

  7. Amended version comes back to Senate
  8. Senate must decide: concur (agree) or non-concur (disagree)

  9. See Stage 8

  10. House Defeats Bill or Takes No Action

  11. Bill dies
  12. Senate cannot force House to act

Bill Clerk Action (Senate Side):

  • Code bill as "sent to House"
  • Track when House acts
  • Code House passage or amendments

Timeline: House process can take weeks or months. Bill Clerks monitor House activity for Senate bills.

docs.title: Stage 8: Concurrence or Conference Committee
docs.text: If House Amends a Senate Bill:

docs.title: Option A: Senate Concurs
docs.text:
• Senate votes to accept House amendments
  • Requires majority vote (20 votes)
  • If Senate concurs, bill goes to Governor
  • Bill Clerk Action: Code "Senate concurred in House amendments"

Example: "The question being on concurrence in House amendments to Senate Bill 143. The Senate concurred. Yeas 24, Nays 14."

docs.title: Option B: Senate Non-Concurs
docs.text:
• Senate rejects House amendments
  • Senate can request Conference Committee
  • Bill Clerk Action: Code "Senate non-concurred in House amendments"

Example: "The question being on concurrence in House amendments to Senate Bill 143. The Senate non-concurred. Senator Jones moves that a Conference Committee be appointed."

docs.title: Conference Committee Process:
docs.text:
• 3 Senators and 3 Representatives appointed
  • Committee negotiates compromise between versions
  • Produces a Conference Report
  • Both chambers must approve Conference Report (no amendments allowed)
  • If both approve: bill goes to Governor
  • If either rejects: bill dies (or new conference committee formed)

Bill Clerk Action for Conference:

  • Code appointment of conferees
  • Track Conference Report
  • Record votes on Conference Report in Senate

docs.title: Stage 9: Governor's Action
docs.text:
Once Bill Passes Both Chambers in Identical Form: Bill is "enrolled" (officially prepared) and sent to Governor.

Governor Has Three Options:

docs.title: Option 1: Sign the Bill ✍️
docs.text:
• Governor signs bill into law
  • Becomes a Public Act (PA)
  • Receives PA number (PA 1 of 2026, PA 2 of 2026, etc.)
  • Takes effect based on immediate effect vote:
  • If immediate effect: Takes effect upon signing
  • If no immediate effect: Takes effect 90 days after Legislature adjourns for the year

docs.title: Option 2: Veto the Bill 🚫
docs.text:
• Governor rejects bill
  • Sends veto message back to Legislature
  • Legislature can override veto with 2/3 vote in both chambers (26 in Senate, 74 in House)
  • Override is rare but possible
  • If override succeeds: becomes law without Governor's signature

docs.title: Option 3: Do Nothing (Pocket Veto) ⏱️
docs.text:
• Governor neither signs nor vetoes
  • If Legislature is in session: Bill becomes law after 14 days without signature
  • If Legislature has adjourned for the year: Bill dies (true pocket veto)

Bill Clerk Action:

  • Code bill as "enrolled and sent to Governor"
  • Track Governor's action
  • Record PA number if signed
  • Code veto if applicable
  • Track override attempts

docs.text:
Senate Bill 250: Rural Broadband Funding Act

  • January 15: Senator Martinez introduces SB 250 (First Reading)

  • February 17: Bill placed on General Orders calendar
  • February 24: General Orders - 2 floor amendments adopted, bill advanced to Third Reading
  • February 24: Five-day rule begins (bill available in final form)
  • March 1: Eligible for final vote (5 days passed)
  • March 3: Third Reading - Bill passed, Yeas 30, Nays 8
  • March 3: Immediate effect vote - Yeas 27, Nays 11 - Immediate effect granted
  • March 5: Bill sent to House
  • March 8: House First Reading, referred to Energy and Environment Committee
  • April 14: House committee reports bill "do pass as amended" (added reporting requirements)
  • May 2: House General Orders - amendments debated
  • May 5: House Third Reading - Bill passed, Yeas 72, Nays 38
  • May 5: House immediate effect vote - Yeas 75, Nays 35 - Immediate effect granted
  • May 7: Bill returned to Senate with House amendments

  • May 12: Conference Committee requested and appointed
  • May 20: Conference Committee meets and negotiates compromise

docs.title: Common Ways Bills Die
docs.text: Most bills do NOT become law. Here's where they typically fail:

docs.title: 1. Dies in Committee (Most Common)
docs.text:
• Committee chair never schedules hearing
  • Committee votes down bill
  • Committee postpones indefinitely
  • Estimate: 60-70% of bills die in committee

docs.title: 2. Fails on Third Reading
docs.text:
• Cannot get 20 votes for passage
  • Political opposition too strong

docs.title: 3. Fails in Other Chamber
docs.text:
• House kills Senate bill (or vice versa)
  • Committee in other chamber blocks bill
  • Other chamber runs out of time

docs.title: 4. Conference Committee Fails
docs.text:
• Cannot reach compromise
  • One chamber rejects Conference Report

docs.title: 5. Governor Vetoes
docs.text: • Override attempt fails (need 2/3 in both chambers)

docs.title: 6. Time Runs Out
docs.text:
• Legislature adjourns before completing process
  • Bills do not carry over to next session
  • Must be reintroduced in new session

docs.title: 7. Procedural Errors
docs.text:
• Five-day rule violated
  • Improper committee referral
  • Constitutional problems discovered

Key Insight: The system is designed to make passing laws difficult. This ensures only bills with broad support become law.

docs.title: Key Terminology for Bill Clerks
docs.text: Term Meaning First Reading Bill introduced and given number Second Reading General Orders (Committee of the Whole) Third Reading Final passage vote General Orders Committee of the Whole; amendment stage Five-Day Rule Bill must be available 5 calendar days before final vote Immediate Effect Law takes effect immediately upon signing (requires 2/3 vote) Enrolled Bill officially prepared after passing both chambers Public Act (PA) Enacted law (e.g., PA 85 of 2026) Concur Agree to other chamber's amendments Non-Concur Reject other chamber's amendments Conference Committee Joint committee to resolve House-Senate differences Conference Report Compromise version from conference committee Veto Governor rejects bill Override Legislature passes bill over Governor's veto (2/3 vote) Pocket Veto Bill dies when Governor takes no action after adjournment

docs.title: Self-Check Quiz
docs.text: Question 1: What are the three readings a bill must receive?  **Answer:**  1. **First Reading:** Introduction and assignment to committee 2. **Second Reading:** General Orders (Committee of the Whole) - debate and amendment stage 3. **Third Reading:** Final passage vote  Note: In practice, First Reading is just reading the bill number/title, Second Reading is General Orders, and Third Reading is the final vote.   Question 2: A bill is placed on the Third Reading calendar on Monday, March 3. What is the earliest date the Senate can vote on final passage?  **Answer:** Saturday, March 8 (five full calendar days later). The five-day rule requires 5 calendar days (not session days) to pass before final vote.   Question 3: How many votes are needed to pass a bill in the Senate? How many for immediate effect?  **Answer:**  - **20 votes** (majority of 38) needed for passage - **26 votes** (2/3 of 38) needed for immediate effect  Question 4: What happens during General Orders (Committee of the Whole)?  **Answer:** General Orders is the stage where the full Senate debates the bill and considers amendments. Senators can offer floor amendments, which are voted on. After debate and amendments, the Senate votes to advance the bill to Third Reading. This is a less formal stage than Third Reading.   Question 5: The House passes a Senate bill with amendments. What are the Senate's options?  **Answer:**  1. **Concur** - Accept the House amendments (requires 20 votes); bill goes to Governor 2. **Non-concur** - Reject the House amendments; typically leads to requesting a Conference Committee to negotiate a compromise  Question 6: What are the three options the Governor has when a bill reaches their desk?  **Answer:**  1. **Sign** - Bill becomes a Public Act (law) 2. **Veto** - Reject the bill (Legislature can override with 2/3 vote) 3. **Do Nothing** - Bill becomes law after 14 days if Legislature is in session; dies if Legislature has adjourned (pocket veto)  Question 7: A bill passes the Senate and House with immediate effect. When does the law take effect if the Governor signs it?  **Answer:** Immediately upon the Governor's signature. The immediate effect clause allows laws to take effect right away instead of waiting 90 days after session ends.   Question 8: What is the most common way bills die in the Legislature?  **Answer:** Dying in committee (no action taken). The committee chair simply never schedules a hearing on the bill, or the committee votes it down. Approximately 60-70% of bills die in committee.   Question 9: True or False: If both chambers pass a bill but in different forms, the bill can still go to the Governor.  **Answer:** False. Both chambers must pass the bill in **identical form** before it goes to the Governor. If the versions differ, the chambers must resolve the differences (through concurrence or conference committee).   Question 10: What is a Conference Report and when is it used?  **Answer:** A Conference Report is a compromise version of a bill created by a Conference Committee (3 Senators + 3 Representatives) when the two chambers pass different versions and cannot reach agreement through concurrence. Both chambers must approve the Conference Report without amendments for the bill to proceed to the Governor.   Question 11: Without immediate effect, when do Michigan laws take effect?  **Answer:** 90 days after the Legislature adjourns for the year (sine die adjournment). This is why most bills include immediate effect clauses.   Question 12: Can amendments be offered during Third Reading?  **Answer:** Generally no. Third Reading is for final passage vote only. Amendments are debated and adopted during General Orders (Second Reading). Amendments during Third Reading require special consent, which is rare.

docs.title: Practical Exercise: Track This Bill
docs.text:
Scenario: You're a Bill Clerk watching Senate proceedings.

Senator Williams announces: "Mr. President, I introduce Senate Bill 421, to amend the Natural Resources and Environmental Protection Act regarding wetlands conservation."

President of Senate: "Senate Bill 421, first reading. The bill is referred to the Committee on Natural Resources and Agriculture."

Two weeks later, Committee Chair announces: "The Committee on Natural Resources and Agriculture reports Senate Bill 421 with the recommendation 'do pass as amended' and refers the bill to the Committee on Appropriations."

Three weeks later, Appropriations Committee reports: "The Committee on Appropriations reports Senate Bill 421 with the recommendation 'do pass.'"

One week later, on General Orders: "Senate Bill 421 is before the Senate on General Orders. Senator Williams explains the bill. Senator Jackson offers Floor Amendment 1... Amendment adopted by voice vote. Senator Lee moves the bill be advanced to Third Reading. Motion carried."

The next day: "Senate Bill 421 has been on Third Reading for one day. It is not yet eligible for final vote under the five-day rule."

Five days later: "Third Reading of Senate Bill 421. The question being on passage of the bill. The bill passed, Yeas 28, Nays 10. Senator Williams moves immediate effect. The question being on immediate effect. Yeas 27, Nays 11. Immediate effect is granted."

Questions for you:

  1. What committees reviewed this bill?
  2. How many times was the bill amended (that you can tell)?
  3. How many days must pass before Third Reading vote?
  4. Did immediate effect pass?
  5. What happens next?
Answers: 1. **Two committees:** Natural Resources and Agriculture (policy committee), then Appropriations (fiscal committee) 2. **Twice:** Once in Natural Resources committee ("do pass as amended") and once on General Orders (Floor Amendment 1) 3. **5 calendar days** after being placed on Third Reading 4. **Yes**, immediate effect passed with 27 votes (needs 26) 5. **Bill is sent to the House** for the House to go through its own process (first reading, committee, General Orders, Third Reading)

docs.title: Notes for Instructor Q&A
docs.text:
Q: What if a bill needs more than 5 days on Third Reading? A: The five-day rule is a minimum. Bills can sit on Third Reading for weeks or months if leadership doesn't schedule the vote.

Q: Can the five-day rule be waived? A: Yes, but only by 2/3 vote of the Senate, and it's very rare. Usually reserved for true emergencies.

Q: What happens if the Senate violates the five-day rule? A: The vote can be challenged and ruled invalid. The law could be struck down in court. It's a serious procedural error.

Q: How do I know if a bill needs to go to Appropriations? A: Listen for fiscal impact statements. If a bill spends state money, it usually goes to Appropriations. Bills often go to policy committee first, then Appropriations.

Q: What if the House makes dozens of amendments? A: The Senate can concur in all of them, non-concur and request conference, or (rarely) concur in some and not others (requires special procedures).

Q: Do I need to memorize all these stages? A: Yes. You'll see this process hundreds of times. After a few weeks, it becomes second nature. Focus on understanding the flow and the vote requirements.

docs.title: Key Takeaways
docs.text: ✅ Bills must receive three readings (Introduction, General Orders, Third Reading) ✅ Five-day rule: Bill must be available 5 calendar days before final vote ✅ 20 votes for passage, 26 votes for immediate effect ✅ Both chambers must pass identical versions ✅ Most bills die in committee (never get a hearing) ✅ Governor can sign, veto, or do nothing ✅ Bill Clerks track every step accurately in real-time

docs.text: By the end of this module, you will be able to: - List all 17 Michigan Senate standing committees and their jurisdictions - Describe the roles of committee chairs, vice chairs, and members - Explain committee procedures including hearings, votes, and reports - Code committee actions accurately as a Bill Clerk - Understand special situations like discharge motions and multiple referrals - Recognize the special role of the Appropriations Committee

docs.title: Why Committees Matter
docs.text:
Committees are where the real work of the Legislature happens. They: - Screen bills: Most bills die in committee (60-70%) - Hold hearings: Gather expert testimony and public input - Amend bills: Make technical and policy changes - Conduct oversight: Review state agencies and programs - Develop expertise: Members specialize in policy areas

For Bill Clerks: You must accurately code which committee has a bill, what action the committee took, and when bills are reported back to the full Senate.

docs.title: The 17 Michigan Senate Standing Committees (2025-2026 Session)
1. Appropriations Committee
docs.text:
Jurisdiction: State budget, funding for all state operations and programs

Why Special: - Controls the purse strings - All bills with fiscal impact (spending state money) eventually go here - Often the last committee to see a bill before floor action - Largest committee with most members - Has subcommittees for different budget areas (education, health, transportation, etc.) - Committee of jurisdiction for budget bills

Typical Path: Policy committee → Appropriations → Floor

Example Bills: - State budget bills - K-12 school aid budget - Bills creating new state programs (after policy committee approves policy) - Bills expanding existing programs

Bill Clerk Note: If you hear "referred to Appropriations," the bill involves spending money.

docs.title: 2. Civil Rights, Judiciary, and Public Safety Committee
docs.text:
Jurisdiction: - Court system and judicial procedures - Criminal law and sentencing - Civil rights and discrimination law - Prisons and corrections - Law enforcement and police - Domestic violence - Legal system reform

Example Bills: - Sentencing reform - Expungement of criminal records - Police accountability measures - Civil rights protections - Court procedures and rules

docs.title: 3. Economic and Community Development Committee
docs.text:
Jurisdiction: - Economic development initiatives - Small business support - Tourism promotion - Community revitalization - Economic incentives - Regional economic planning - Entrepreneurship

Example Bills: - Business tax incentives - Downtown redevelopment programs - Tourism marketing budgets - Small business loan programs

docs.title: 4. Education Committee
docs.text:
Jurisdiction: - K-12 education policy (not budget - that's Appropriations) - School curriculum and standards - Teacher certification and evaluation - School choice and charter schools - Education accountability - School safety - Special education

Example Bills: - Graduation requirements - Teacher certification rules - School choice expansion - Curriculum standards (reading, math, etc.) - School disciplinary policies

Note: Education budget goes to Appropriations; education policy comes here first.

docs.title: 5. Elections and Ethics Committee
docs.text:
Jurisdiction: - Election law and procedures - Voter registration - Campaign finance - Legislative ethics - Redistricting - Ballot initiatives - Absentee voting rules

Example Bills: - Voter ID requirements - Campaign contribution limits - Ethics rules for legislators - Election security measures - Absentee ballot procedures

docs.title: 6. Energy and Environment Committee
docs.text:
Jurisdiction: - Energy policy and regulation - Utilities (electric, gas, water) - Environmental protection - Climate policy - Renewable energy - Oil and gas regulation - Air and water quality

Example Bills: - Renewable energy standards - Utility rate regulation - Environmental cleanup programs - Energy efficiency standards - Pipeline safety

docs.title: 7. Finance, Insurance, and Consumer Protection Committee
docs.text:
Jurisdiction: - Banking and financial institutions - Insurance regulation - Consumer protection laws - Financial services regulation - Credit and lending - Debt collection - Identity theft

Example Bills: - Insurance rate regulations - Consumer fraud prevention - Banking regulations - Cryptocurrency regulation - Predatory lending protections

docs.title: 8. Government Operations Committee
docs.text:
Jurisdiction: - State government structure and organization - Civil service and state employees - Administrative procedures - Open records and transparency - FOIA (Freedom of Information Act) - State contracts and procurement - Government efficiency

Example Bills: - State agency reorganization - Civil service reforms - FOIA expansions or exemptions - State purchasing rules - Government transparency measures

docs.title: 9. Health Policy Committee
docs.text:
Jurisdiction: - Healthcare policy and regulation - Medicaid (but not budget) - Public health - Health insurance - Hospitals and medical facilities - Mental health services - Prescription drugs - Healthcare workforce

Example Bills: - Medicaid expansion or restrictions - Hospital regulations - Mental health parity - Prescription drug pricing - Telehealth rules - Healthcare provider licensing

docs.title: 10. Housing and Human Services Committee
docs.text:
Jurisdiction: - Affordable housing - Homeless services - Welfare programs (TANF, food assistance) - Child welfare and foster care - Family services - Adoption - Senior services

Example Bills: - Affordable housing incentives - Foster care reforms - Welfare eligibility and benefits - Homeless assistance programs - Senior citizen services

docs.title: 11. Labor Committee
docs.text:
Jurisdiction: - Employment law - Workers' compensation - Unemployment insurance - Workplace safety (OSHA) - Labor unions and collective bargaining - Minimum wage - Right-to-work laws - Workplace discrimination

Example Bills: - Minimum wage adjustments - Paid leave policies - Workers' compensation reforms - Workplace safety standards - Union organizing rules

docs.title: 12. Local Government Committee
docs.text:
Jurisdiction: - County, city, township government - Local taxation and finance - Municipal services - Intergovernmental relations - Local government authority - Annexation and incorporation - Local revenue sharing

Example Bills: - Local tax authority - County governance structures - Revenue sharing formulas - Local government consolidation - Municipal service delivery

docs.title: 13. Natural Resources and Agriculture Committee
docs.text:
Jurisdiction: - Farming and agriculture - Forestry - Wildlife and hunting/fishing - State parks and recreation - Department of Natural Resources oversight - Agricultural economics - Conservation - Land use

Example Bills: - Hunting and fishing regulations - Agricultural subsidies or regulations - Forestry management - State park improvements - Conservation easements - Farm labor issues

docs.title: 14. Oversight Committee
docs.text:
Jurisdiction: - Investigation of state agencies - Government accountability - Waste, fraud, and abuse - Program effectiveness - Agency audits - Regulatory review

Special Purpose: - Investigative committee - Can subpoena witnesses and documents - Often deals with controversies and scandals - May not handle many regular bills

Example Activities: - Investigating agency mismanagement - Reviewing state contracts for fraud - Holding hearings on program failures

docs.title: 15. Regulatory Affairs Committee
docs.text:
Jurisdiction: - Professional licensing (doctors, lawyers, plumbers, etc.) - Occupational regulations - Professional boards - Business licensing - Regulatory reform - Administrative rules review

Example Bills: - Licensing requirements for professions - Occupational regulation reforms - Professional board authority - Regulatory barriers to entry

docs.title: 16. Transportation and Infrastructure Committee
docs.text:
Jurisdiction: - Roads and bridges - Public transportation - Transportation funding - Road commissions - Airports - Railroads - Infrastructure investment - Vehicle regulations (some)

Example Bills: - Gas tax increases - Road funding formulas - Public transit funding - Transportation infrastructure bonds - Road construction standards

docs.title: 17. Veterans and Emergency Services Committee
docs.text:
Jurisdiction: - Veterans' benefits and services - Military affairs - Emergency management - Homeland security - Disaster response - State military facilities - Veterans' homes

Example Bills: - Veterans' benefits - Military base support - Emergency preparedness - Veterans' healthcare access - Disaster relief programs

docs.title: Committee Chair
docs.text:
Appointed by: Majority Leader

Powers: - Sets committee agenda - Decides which bills get hearings - Chairs committee meetings - Controls debate and recognition - Most important power: Can kill bills by never scheduling hearings - From majority party

Influence: The chair controls the committee. If chair opposes a bill, it rarely moves forward.

docs.title: Majority Vice Chair
docs.text:
Appointed by: Majority Leader

Role: - From majority party - Assists chair - Presides when chair is absent - May have special responsibilities (e.g., budget subcommittees)

docs.title: Minority Vice Chair
docs.text:
Appointed by: Majority Leader

Role: - From minority party - Represents minority party interests on committee - Presides when both chair and majority vice chair are absent - Provides minority perspective in committee deliberations

docs.title: Committee Members
docs.text:
• Attend hearings and meetings
  • Question witnesses
  • Offer amendments
  • Vote on bills
  • Typically 5-15 members per committee
  • Party ratio usually reflects Senate overall (e.g., if Senate is 20-18, committee might be 5-4)

docs.title: Committee Staff
docs.text:
• Not senators: Professional staff hired by committee
  • Research issues
  • Draft amendments
  • Brief senators
  • Manage logistics of hearings

Bill Clerk Note: You don't code staff actions, only senator actions.

docs.title: 1. Scheduling
docs.text:
• Chair decides when to meet
  • Meetings publicly noticed (usually 5 days advance)
  • Held in Capitol or other state buildings

docs.title: 2. Public Hearings
docs.text:
• Allow citizens, experts, lobbyists to testify
  • Witnesses register in advance or day-of
  • Typical order: Bill sponsor, proponents, opponents, neutral parties, public comment
  • Committee members ask questions

docs.title: 3. Committee Discussion
docs.text:
• Senators debate bill among themselves
  • May request testimony from state agencies
  • Staff provide analysis

docs.title: 4. Amendments
docs.text:
• Committee members offer amendments
  • Committee votes on amendments
  • Amendments can make small or large changes

docs.title: 5. Committee Vote
docs.text:
• Chair calls for vote on bill
  • Voice vote or roll call
  • Majority of committee members present must vote yes to report bill

docs.title: 6. Committee Report
docs.text:
• If bill passes committee, it's "reported" back to full Senate
  • Report includes committee recommendation (see next section)

docs.title: Committee Actions Bill Clerks Must Code
docs.text: When a committee acts on a bill, Bill Clerks must accurately code the action. Here are the possible outcomes:

docs.title: 1. Reported with Recommendation "Do Pass"
docs.text:
What it means: Committee approves bill as written, no changes

Bill Clerk Code: "Committee reports SB X with recommendation 'do pass'"

What happens next: Bill goes to General Orders (Committee of the Whole)

Example: "The Committee on Transportation and Infrastructure reports Senate Bill 145 with the recommendation 'do pass.'"

docs.title: 2. Reported with Recommendation "Do Pass as Amended"
docs.text:
What it means: Committee made changes (amendments) and approves amended version

Bill Clerk Code: "Committee reports SB X with recommendation 'do pass as amended'"

What happens next: Bill goes to General Orders with committee amendments

Example: "The Committee on Health Policy reports Senate Bill 212 with the recommendation 'do pass as amended.'"

Note: The amendments become part of the bill unless General Orders rejects them.

docs.title: 3. Reported with Committee Substitute (CS)
docs.text:
What it means: Committee rewrote significant portions; original bill replaced with substitute

Bill Clerk Code: "Committee reports SB X with substitute (committee substitute)"

What happens next: Substitute goes to General Orders (original version is gone)

Example: "The Committee on Education reports Senate Bill 78 with a committee substitute."

Note: Substitutes are major rewrites. Original sponsor may not even recognize the bill.

docs.title: 4. Referred to Another Committee
docs.text:
What it means: Committee sends bill to different committee for review

Bill Clerk Code: "Committee refers SB X to [Committee Name]"

What happens next: Bill goes to the other committee (starts committee process over)

Common scenarios: - Policy committee → Appropriations (bill has fiscal impact) - One policy committee → Different policy committee (jurisdictional issues) - Substantive committee → Oversight (investigation needed)

Example: "The Committee on Natural Resources and Agriculture reports Senate Bill 198 and refers the bill to the Committee on Appropriations."

Note: This is NOT a negative action. The first committee may have approved it but recognized fiscal impact.

docs.title: 5. Postponed
docs.text:
What it means: Committee delays decision, may reconsider later

Bill Clerk Code: "Committee postponed SB X"

What happens next: Bill stays in committee, may come back up for vote (or may never be seen again)

Reasons for postponement: - Need more information - Waiting for fiscal analysis - Political timing issues - Sponsor requested delay to work on amendments - Close vote, chair wants to delay until more members present

Example: "The Committee on Labor postponed consideration of Senate Bill 334."

docs.title: 6. No Action / No Report
docs.text:
What it means: Committee never votes on bill, or votes it down

Bill Clerk Code: Usually nothing to code (absence of action)

What happens next: Bill dies in committee

Most common outcome: Chair never schedules hearing, or committee votes "no" on reporting bill

Note: If committee votes down a bill, you might hear "motion to report failed" but often there's just silence - bill never emerges from committee.

docs.title: 7. Discharged from Committee (Rare)
docs.text:
What it means: Full Senate votes to take bill away from committee

Bill Clerk Code: "Senate discharged [Committee] from further consideration of SB X"

What happens next: Bill goes to floor without committee recommendation

How it happens: - Requires motion and majority vote on Senate floor - Used when committee chair is blocking popular bill - Rare because it's seen as insulting to committee and chair - Usually requires bipartisan support

Example: "Senator Martinez moved to discharge the Committee on Elections and Ethics from further consideration of Senate Bill 56. Motion carried, Yeas 22, Nays 16."

docs.title: Multiple Referrals (Sequential)
docs.text:
What it is: Bill goes to one committee, then another, in sequence

Common pattern: Policy committee → Appropriations

Example: "The Committee on Health Policy reports Senate Bill 401 with the recommendation 'do pass as amended' and refers the bill to the Committee on Appropriations."

Bill Clerk Action: Code both the committee recommendation AND the referral to next committee

Why it happens: Bill has both policy implications (first committee) and fiscal impact (Appropriations)

docs.title: Subcommittees
docs.text:
What they are: Smaller groups within a committee that focus on specific areas

Most common in: Appropriations Committee - Appropriations has subcommittees for: Education, Health, Transportation, etc. - Each subcommittee handles budget bills for its area

Process: 1. Bill referred to full Appropriations Committee 2. Chair assigns to subcommittee 3. Subcommittee holds hearing and votes 4. Subcommittee reports to full committee 5. Full committee votes 6. Full committee reports to Senate floor

Bill Clerk Action: Code subcommittee reports separately from full committee reports

Example: "The Appropriations Subcommittee on Education reports Senate Bill 501 to the full Appropriations Committee with recommendation 'do pass.'"

docs.title: Joint Committee Hearings
docs.text:
What they are: Senate and House committees meet together to hear testimony

Why: Save time when both chambers considering similar bills

Bill Clerk Note: Each chamber's committee still votes separately and reports separately

docs.title: Committee of the Whole (Not a Standing Committee!)
docs.text:
What it is: The entire Senate acting as one committee (General Orders stage)

Not a standing committee: It's a procedural stage (covered in Module 4)

Difference: - Standing committees: 5-15 senators, closed process - Committee of the Whole: All 38 senators, floor debate

docs.title: The Appropriations Committee: A Special Case
docs.text: The Appropriations Committee deserves extra attention because it's unique:

docs.title: Why Appropriations is Different:
docs.text:
1. All spending bills go here eventually
  2. Even if bill starts in another committee

  3. Appropriations has "last look" at fiscal impact

  4. Largest committee

  5. More members than other committees

  6. Divided into subcommittees

  7. Budget bills originate here

  8. State budget starts in Appropriations

  9. Education budget, department budgets, etc.

  10. More staff support

  11. Fiscal analysts

  12. Budget experts

  13. Special power

  14. Can effectively kill bills by declaring them "too expensive"
  15. Can demand offsets (spending cuts elsewhere to pay for new spending)

"do pass"  "do pass as amended"

Bill goes to General Orders and Third Reading

docs.title: Fiscal Notes
docs.text:
• All bills with spending get a "fiscal note" (cost estimate)
  • Prepared by nonpartisan analysts
  • Appropriations Committee reviews fiscal notes
  • Committee may amend bill to reduce costs

Bill Clerk Note: When you see a bill referred to Appropriations, you know it spends money.

docs.title: Who Can Testify:
docs.text:
• Bill sponsors (always go first)
  • Citizens
  • Interest groups and lobbyists
  • Experts (academics, researchers)
  • State agency officials
  • Local government representatives

docs.title: How Public Hearings Work:
docs.text:
1. Committee chair opens hearing
  2. Bill sponsor presents bill
  3. Proponents testify
  4. Opponents testify
  5. Neutral parties testify
  6. Public comment (if time allows)
  7. Committee members ask questions
  8. Chair closes hearing

docs.title: Important for Bill Clerks:
docs.text:
• You don't code public testimony
  • You only code committee actions (votes, reports, referrals)
  • Hearings can last hours, but the vote takes seconds

docs.title: Self-Check Quiz
docs.text: Question 1: List 10 of the 17 Michigan Senate standing committees.  **Answer:** (Any 10 of these) 1. Appropriations 2. Civil Rights, Judiciary, and Public Safety 3. Economic and Community Development 4. Education 5. Elections and Ethics 6. Energy and Environment 7. Finance, Insurance, and Consumer Protection 8. Government Operations 9. Health Policy 10. Housing and Human Services 11. Labor 12. Local Government 13. Natural Resources and Agriculture 14. Oversight 15. Regulatory Affairs 16. Transportation and Infrastructure 17. Veterans and Emergency Services  Question 2: Which committee handles all bills with fiscal impact?  **Answer:** The Appropriations Committee. Bills with spending often go to a policy committee first, then are referred to Appropriations for fiscal review.  Question 3: What is the difference between "reported with recommendation do pass" and "reported with recommendation do pass as amended"?  **Answer:**  - **"Do pass"** means the committee approves the bill as written with no changes - **"Do pass as amended"** means the committee made amendments (changes) and approves the amended version  Question 4: Who has the most power in a committee and why?  **Answer:** The committee chair has the most power because the chair decides which bills get hearings. If the chair doesn't schedule a hearing, the bill dies in committee. The chair also sets the agenda, controls debate, and manages committee operations.  Question 5: A bill about K-12 teacher certification is referred to committee. Which committee would it likely go to?  **Answer:** The Education Committee (deals with K-12 policy, including teacher certification, curriculum, and school operations).  Question 6: What does it mean when a committee "refers a bill to another committee"?  **Answer:** The bill is sent to a different committee for additional review. This is common when a bill has both policy implications and fiscal impact (policy committee → Appropriations), or when jurisdiction is unclear. The bill starts the committee process over in the new committee.  Question 7: What is a committee substitute?  **Answer:** A committee substitute is when the committee significantly rewrites a bill. The original bill is replaced with the substitute version, which may be substantially different from what the sponsor introduced.  Question 8: True or False: If a committee postpones a bill, the bill automatically dies.  **Answer:** False. Postponement means the committee delays its decision. The bill may come back up for a vote later (though it often doesn't). The bill only dies if the committee never acts on it or votes it down.  Question 9: What is a discharge motion and when is it used?  **Answer:** A discharge motion is when the full Senate votes to remove a bill from committee and bring it to the floor. It's used (rarely) when a committee chair is blocking a bill that has broader support. Requires a majority vote on the Senate floor and is considered an extraordinary measure.  Question 10: A committee reports a bill "do pass" and refers it to Appropriations. What should a Bill Clerk code?  **Answer:** Code both actions: (1) The committee recommendation "do pass" and (2) the referral to the Appropriations Committee. The bill now goes to Appropriations, not to General Orders.  Question 11: What committee would handle a bill about: (a) Medicaid expansion, (b) minimum wage increase, (c) hunting regulations?  **Answer:**  - (a) **Health Policy** (Medicaid policy) - then likely Appropriations (fiscal impact) - (b) **Labor** (employment law, wages) - (c) **Natural Resources and Agriculture** (wildlife, hunting/fishing regulations)  Question 12: What is the most common way bills die?  **Answer:** Dying in committee through inaction. The committee chair never schedules a hearing, or the committee votes not to report the bill. Approximately 60-70% of bills die in committee.

docs.title: Practice Scenario: Coding Committee Actions
docs.text:
You're a Bill Clerk listening to committee reports. Code each action:

Scenario 1: "The Committee on Transportation and Infrastructure reports Senate Bill 789 with the recommendation 'do pass.'"

What do you code? **Answer:** Committee action: Reported with recommendation "do pass" Committee: Transportation and Infrastructure Bill: SB 789 Next stage: Bill goes to General Orders

Scenario 2: "The Committee on Education reports Senate Bill 234 with the recommendation 'do pass as amended' and refers the bill to the Committee on Appropriations."

What do you code? **Answer:** Committee action: Reported "do pass as amended" + referred to Appropriations Committee: Education Bill: SB 234 Next committee: Appropriations Note: Bill does NOT go to General Orders yet; goes to Appropriations first

Scenario 3: "The Committee on Health Policy reports Senate Bill 567 with a committee substitute."

What do you code? **Answer:** Committee action: Reported with committee substitute Committee: Health Policy Bill: SB 567 Next stage: Committee substitute version goes to General Orders Note: Original bill replaced with substitute

Scenario 4: "The Committee on Appropriations postponed consideration of Senate Bill 445."

What do you code? **Answer:** Committee action: Postponed Committee: Appropriations Bill: SB 445 Next stage: Bill stays in committee; may be reconsidered later (or may die)

docs.title: Notes for Instructor Q&A
docs.text:
Q: How do I know which committee a bill should go to if the subject overlaps multiple committees? A: Senate leadership (primarily the Majority Leader) makes the final decision. Some bills could go to multiple committees. Listen for the referral announcement. Don't guess - wait for the official referral.

Q: Can a bill skip committee? A: Extremely rare. Theoretically possible with a discharge motion, but virtually all bills go through committee. The committee process is considered essential.

Q: What if I miss which committee a bill was referred to? A: Check the Senate Journal (official record) or ask your supervisor. Never guess on committee referrals.

Q: Do I need to know every committee member's name? A: Not initially, but you'll learn the committee chairs quickly. Focus on knowing the 17 committees and their jurisdictions first.

Q: What if a committee reports a bill and I'm not sure if it's "do pass" or "do pass as amended"? A: Listen carefully for "as amended." If you're unsure, flag it and ask your supervisor. Accuracy is critical.

docs.title: Key Takeaways

docs.title: Overview: The Senate Floor
docs.text:
The Senate floor is where the full body of 38 Senators meets to debate and vote on legislation. As a Bill Clerk, this is where you'll spend most of your time - listening, tracking, and coding actions in real-time.

Key Skills for Bill Clerks: - Listen carefully to parliamentary language - Identify motions and track their outcomes - Record votes accurately (counts and results) - Code amendments (who offered, result) - Track bill progress through floor stages - Work quickly - floor moves fast during busy sessions

docs.title: Order of Business: How a Senate Session Works
docs.text: Michigan Senate sessions follow a standard order of business:

docs.title: 1. Call to Order
docs.text:
• President of Senate (Lt. Governor) or President Pro Tem gavels session to start
  • Time noted (e.g., "Senate called to order at 10:00 a.m.")

docs.title: 2. Invocation and Pledge
docs.text:
• Opening prayer (rotating religious leaders)
  • Pledge of Allegiance

docs.title: 3. Roll Call
docs.text:
• Secretary calls roll to establish quorum
  • Quorum = majority of members (20 of 38)
  • Without quorum, Senate cannot conduct business

docs.title: 4. Messages from the Governor
docs.text: • Communications from Governor (veto messages, appointments, etc.)

docs.title: 5. Messages from the House
docs.text:
• Bills passed by House and sent to Senate
  • House amendments to Senate bills
  • Conference reports

docs.title: 6. Introduction and First Reading of Bills
docs.text:
• New bills introduced
  • Read by title
  • Referred to committee

docs.title: 7. Statements
docs.text:
• Senators may make brief statements on any topic
  • Not related to pending legislation

docs.title: 8. Committee Reports
docs.text:
• Committees report bills back to Senate
  • Bills placed on General Orders or Third Reading

docs.title: 9. General Orders (Committee of the Whole)
docs.text:
• Debate and amendment of bills
  • Less formal than Third Reading
  • Most floor action happens here

docs.title: 10. Third Reading of Bills
docs.text:
• Final passage votes
  • Immediate effect votes

docs.title: 11. Resolutions
docs.text:
• Ceremonial resolutions
  • Policy resolutions

docs.title: 12. Announcements and Committee Meetings
docs.text:
• Upcoming committee meetings
  • Schedule changes

docs.title: 13. Adjournment
docs.text:
• Motion to adjourn
  • Gaveled out

Bill Clerk Note: Not every session includes all items. Routine sessions may skip ahead to General Orders and Third Reading.

docs.title: What is General Orders?
docs.text: General Orders is when the entire Senate (38 members) acts as one large committee to debate and amend bills. It's also called "Committee of the Whole" or "Second Reading."

docs.title: Why "Committee of the Whole"?
docs.text: Historically, legislative bodies would reconstitute themselves as a committee to allow more informal debate. The entire membership becomes a committee.

docs.title: Key Characteristics:
docs.text:
• Less formal than Third Reading
  • Amendments allowed freely (don't need special permission)
  • Voice votes common for amendments (vs. roll calls)
  • Debate is more flexible
  • President may yield gavel to President Pro Tem
  • Senate rules relaxed slightly

docs.title: Purpose of General Orders:
docs.text:
1. Amendment stage: This is where most amendments are offered and debated
  2. Work out details: Senators perfect the language
  3. Build consensus: Negotiate changes to gain support
  4. Second look: Full Senate reviews committee's work
