docs.title: Bill Clerk Actions on General Orders:
docs.text:
Listen for: - Bill number and sponsor - Amendments offered (floor amendment numbers: FA 1, FA 2, etc.) - Vote results on amendments (adopted/defeated) - Motion to advance to Third Reading - Vote on motion to advance

Code: - Each amendment offered - Result of each amendment vote - Final action (advanced to Third Reading or not)

Example: "Senate Bill 342 is before the Senate on General Orders. Senator Davis explains the bill. Senator Thompson offers Floor Amendment 1 to Senate Bill 342. Voice vote: Amendment adopted. Senator Lee offers Floor Amendment 2. Roll call: Yeas 18, Nays 20. Amendment defeated. Senator Davis moves the bill be advanced to Third Reading. Voice vote: Motion carried. Bill advanced to Third Reading."

docs.title: 1. Committee Amendments
docs.text:
• Already part of bill from committee
  • Senate can adopt or reject committee amendments on General Orders
  • Usually adopted without much debate (committee already reviewed)

docs.title: 2. Floor Amendments
docs.text:
• Offered by individual Senators during General Orders
  • Numbered sequentially: FA 1, FA 2, FA 3, etc.
  • Can be simple (technical fixes) or substantive (major policy changes)

docs.title: 3. Substitute Amendments
docs.text:
• Replace entire bill with new language
  • Rare on floor (more common in committee)

docs.title: 4. Amendments to Amendments
docs.text:
• Amending an amendment before voting on it
  • Can get complex quickly

docs.title: Amendment Process:
docs.text:
1. Senator offers amendment: "I offer Floor Amendment 1 to Senate Bill X"
  2. Amendment is read or explained
  3. Debate on amendment (if any)
  4. Vote on amendment: Voice vote or roll call
  5. Result announced: "Amendment adopted" or "Amendment defeated"
  6. Repeat for each amendment

docs.title: Amendment Numbering:
docs.text:
• Floor amendments numbered in order offered: FA 1, FA 2, FA 3...
  • Numbering is per bill (SB 100 FA 1, SB 101 FA 1, etc.)
  • Committee amendments may have different designations

docs.title: Friendly vs. Hostile Amendments:
docs.text:
• Friendly: Bill sponsor supports amendment
  • Hostile: Bill sponsor opposes amendment
  • Both are voted on the same way

Bill Clerk Note: You code all amendments and results, regardless of whether they're friendly or hostile.

docs.title: Amendment Adoption:
docs.text:
• Voice vote most common on General Orders
  • Roll call vote if requested by any Senator
  • Majority required to adopt amendment (20 of 38 if all present)

docs.title: 1. Voice Vote 🗣️
docs.text:
How it works: - President: "All in favor say 'aye.' All opposed say 'no.'" - Senators respond verbally - President determines outcome based on volume - No individual record of who voted how

When used: - Most amendments on General Orders - Non-controversial motions - Procedural matters - Resolutions

Bill Clerk Code: "Voice vote: Motion carried" or "Voice vote: Motion failed"

Note: Voice votes are quick but don't provide individual accountability.

docs.title: 2. Roll Call Vote 📊
docs.text:
How it works: - Secretary calls each Senator's name alphabetically - Each Senator responds: "Yes," "No," or "Pass" - Senators who "pass" can vote when roll call comes back around - Votes recorded individually and publicly - Final tally announced

When required: - Third Reading passage votes (always roll call) - Immediate effect votes (always roll call) - Veto overrides (always roll call) - Conference reports (usually roll call)

When requested: - Any Senator can request roll call on any question - Typical request: "I request a roll call vote"

Bill Clerk Code: Record each Senator's vote and final tally - Example: "Roll call: Yeas 28, Nays 10, Excused 0, Not Voting 0"

Excused vs. Not Voting: - Excused: Absent with permission (illness, other official duty) - Not Voting: Present but chose not to vote (rare; sometimes conflict of interest)

docs.title: 3. Division Vote (Rare) ✋
docs.text:
How it works: - After unclear voice vote, President orders division - Senators in favor stand and are counted - Senators opposed stand and are counted - No individual record (just counts)

When used: - Voice vote outcome unclear - Rarely used in modern practice (roll call more common)

Bill Clerk Code: "Division vote: Yeas 22, Nays 16, Motion carried"

docs.title: Vote Requirements Summary:
docs.text: Action Votes Needed Type of Vote Adopt amendment (GO) Majority present Voice or roll call Advance to Third Reading Majority present (20 if all present) Voice or roll call Pass bill (Third Reading) 20 (majority of 38) Roll call required Immediate effect 26 (2/3 of 38) Roll call required Concur in amendments 20 Roll call usually Conference report 20 Roll call usually Override veto 26 (2/3) Roll call required Procedural motions Majority present Usually voice

docs.title: What is Third Reading?
docs.text: Third Reading is the final, formal vote on a bill. It's the point of no return.

docs.title: Characteristics:
docs.text:
• Very formal (stricter rules than General Orders)
  • No amendments without special consent (unanimous or 2/3 vote)
  • Bill read by title (third time)
  • Roll call vote required for passage
  • Public record of each Senator's position

docs.title: Five-Day Rule Reminder:
docs.text: Before Third Reading vote, bill must have been in its final form and available for 5 calendar days.

docs.title: Third Reading Process:
docs.text:
1. President announces: "Third Reading of Senate Bill X"
  2. Bill read by title (or full reading if requested)
  3. Limited debate (less flexible than General Orders)
  4. President calls the question: "The question being on passage of the bill"
  5. Roll call vote taken
  6. Result announced: "The bill passed" or "The bill failed"
  7. If passed, immediate effect vote (if applicable)

docs.title: Bill Clerk Actions:
docs.text:
Listen for: - Bill number - Vote count (Yeas, Nays, Excused, Not Voting) - Result (passed/failed) - Immediate effect vote (if applicable)

Code: - Third Reading action - Vote totals - Bill passed or failed - Immediate effect result (if applicable)

Example: "Third Reading of Senate Bill 567. The question being on passage of the bill. The Secretary will call the roll. [Roll call occurs] The bill passed. Yeas 32, Nays 6, Excused 0, Not Voting 0."

docs.title: What is Immediate Effect?
docs.text: Michigan laws normally take effect 90 days after the Legislature adjourns for the year. Immediate effect allows a law to take effect immediately upon the Governor's signature.

docs.title: Why It Matters:
docs.text:
• Urgent laws: Emergency measures, time-sensitive issues
  • Budget bills: Need to take effect in fiscal year
  • Most bills: Include immediate effect clause to avoid 90-day delay

docs.title: Voting Requirement:
docs.text: 26 votes (2/3 of 38 Senators) required

docs.title: Process:
docs.text:
1. Bill passes Third Reading (20+ votes)
  2. Sponsor or leader moves immediate effect: "I move immediate effect"
  3. Roll call vote on immediate effect
  4. Result announced

docs.title: Possible Outcomes:
docs.text:
Yeas Result 26+ Immediate effect granted - Law takes effect upon Governor's signature 25 or fewer Immediate effect denied - Law takes effect 90 days after session ends

Important: Bill still becomes law even if immediate effect fails. It just takes effect later.

docs.title: Bill Clerk Actions:
docs.text:
Listen for: - Motion for immediate effect - Vote count on immediate effect - Result (granted or denied)

Code: - Immediate effect vote separately from passage vote - Record Yeas, Nays, Excused, Not Voting - Note result (granted/denied)

Example: "Senator Martinez moves immediate effect. The question being on immediate effect. The Secretary will call the roll. [Roll call] Immediate effect is granted. Yeas 27, Nays 11."

Common Scenario: Bill passes 32-6, but immediate effect passes 25-13. Immediate effect denied (needs 26). Law still becomes law but takes effect in 90 days.

docs.title: Common Floor Motions
docs.text: Bill Clerks must recognize and code motions quickly. Here are the most common:

docs.title: 1. Motion to Advance to Third Reading
docs.text: What it does: Moves bill from General Orders to Third Reading When: After debate/amendments on General Orders Vote needed: Majority Example: "I move the bill be advanced to Third Reading"

docs.title: 2. Motion to Table
docs.text: What it does: Postpones action indefinitely (usually kills the bill) When: To avoid voting on something controversial Vote needed: Majority Example: "I move to table Senate Bill 234" Effect: Bill sits indefinitely, rarely comes back

docs.title: 3. Motion to Postpone
docs.text: What it does: Delays action to specific time When: Need more time, waiting for information Vote needed: Majority Example: "I move to postpone Senate Bill 456 until next session day" Effect: Bill comes back at specified time

docs.title: 4. Motion to Refer (or Re-refer)
docs.text: What it does: Send bill to committee (or back to committee) When: Issues discovered on floor, need committee review Vote needed: Majority Example: "I move to refer Senate Bill 789 to the Committee on Appropriations" Effect: Bill goes to committee

docs.title: 5. Motion to Reconsider
docs.text: What it does: Bring back vote that already happened When: Vote taken hastily, need second look Vote needed: Majority Example: "I move to reconsider the vote by which Senate Bill 321 passed" Timing: Usually must be made same day or next session day Effect: Previous vote nullified, new vote taken

docs.title: 6. Motion to Concur
docs.text: What it does: Accept House amendments to Senate bill When: House passes Senate bill with changes Vote needed: 20 votes Example: "I move the Senate concur in the House amendments to Senate Bill 543" Effect: If passes, bill goes to Governor

docs.title: 7. Motion to Non-Concur
docs.text: What it does: Reject House amendments When: Senate disagrees with House changes Vote needed: Majority Example: "I move the Senate non-concur in the House amendments to Senate Bill 678" Effect: Usually leads to conference committee request

docs.title: 8. Motion for Conference Committee
docs.text: What it does: Request joint Senate-House committee to negotiate When: After non-concurrence Vote needed: Usually adopted by consent Example: "I move that a conference committee be appointed" Effect: President appoints 3 Senators as conferees

docs.title: 9. Motion to Adopt Conference Report
docs.text: What it does: Accept compromise from conference committee When: Conference committee produces report Vote needed: 20 votes Example: "I move the Senate adopt the conference report on Senate Bill 890" Effect: If both chambers adopt, bill goes to Governor

docs.title: 10. Motion to Suspend the Rules
docs.text: What it does: Temporarily ignore a Senate rule When: Emergency, special circumstances Vote needed: 2/3 (26 votes) Example: "I move to suspend the five-day rule on Senate Bill 111" Effect: Rule is waived if motion passes

docs.title: Point of Order
docs.text:
What it is: Senator believes rules are being violated How used: "Mr. President, I rise to a point of order" President's response: Rules on whether objection is valid Can be appealed to full Senate

Bill Clerk Note: Code point of order and President's ruling

docs.title: Appeal of Ruling
docs.text: What it is: Challenge President's ruling on parliamentary question How used: "I appeal the ruling of the chair" Vote: Majority to overturn President's ruling (rare)

docs.title: Quorum Call
docs.text: What it is: Demand to verify quorum (20 Senators present) How used: "I suggest the absence of a quorum" Effect: Roll call to count members present If no quorum: Senate cannot conduct business until quorum established

docs.title: Unanimous Consent
docs.text:
What it is: Ask to do something without formal vote How used: "I ask unanimous consent to..." Effect: If no Senator objects, request granted Common uses: - Skip reading of bill - Extend speaking time - Add co-sponsors

Bill Clerk Note: Code "by unanimous consent" for special actions

docs.title: Division of the Question
docs.text: What it is: Split one question into multiple votes How used: "I move to divide the question" Example: Conference report with multiple provisions - vote on each separately

docs.title: Senate Journal
docs.text: The Senate Journal is the official record of Senate proceedings. As a Bill Clerk, your work may contribute to or reference the Journal.

docs.title: What's in the Journal:
docs.text:
• All votes (roll calls with individual Senator votes)
  • All motions and their results
  • Committee reports
  • Messages from Governor and House
  • Bill introductions and referrals
  • Amendments offered and their results

docs.title: Bill Clerk Connection:
docs.text:
• Your coding creates the real-time record
  • Journal is compiled from daily proceedings
  • Journal is the official legal record
  • Court may reference Journal to interpret legislative intent

docs.title: What to Listen For: Real-Time Coding Guide
During Introduction:
docs.text:
Listen for: - "Senate Bill [number], sponsored by Senator [name]" - Subject of bill (one sentence) - "First reading" - "Referred to Committee on [name]"

Code: Bill number, sponsor, committee referral

docs.title: During Committee Reports:
docs.text:
Listen for: - "Committee on [name] reports Senate Bill [number]" - "With recommendation 'do pass'" or "do pass as amended" or "with substitute" - "Refers the bill to [committee]" (if multiple referrals)

Code: Committee, action, next committee (if applicable)

docs.title: During General Orders:
docs.text:
Listen for: - "Senate Bill [number] is on General Orders" - "Senator [name] offers Floor Amendment [number]" - "Voice vote" or "Roll call" - "Amendment adopted" or "Amendment defeated" - "Motion to advance to Third Reading" - "Motion carried" or "Motion failed"

Code: Each amendment offered, vote results, final motion result

docs.title: During Third Reading:
docs.text:
Listen for: - "Third Reading of Senate Bill [number]" - "The question being on passage of the bill" - Roll call vote totals: "Yeas [number], Nays [number]" - "The bill passed" or "The bill failed" - "Immediate effect?" - then vote totals - "Immediate effect granted" or "Immediate effect denied"

Code: Vote totals, passage result, immediate effect result

docs.title: During House Messages:
docs.text:
Listen for: - "Message from the House: House has passed Senate Bill [number]" - "With amendments" (if applicable) - "Motion to concur" or "Motion to non-concur"

Code: House action, Senate response

docs.title: Self-Check Quiz
docs.text: Question 1: What is General Orders (Committee of the Whole) and what happens there?  **Answer:** General Orders is when the entire Senate (38 members) acts as one committee to debate and amend bills. It's less formal than Third Reading, and this is the primary stage where amendments are offered and debated. After General Orders, bills are advanced to Third Reading for final passage.  Question 2: What are the three types of votes used in the Senate?  **Answer:**  1. **Voice vote** - Senators say "aye" or "no," no individual record 2. **Roll call vote** - Each Senator's vote recorded individually, required for passage and immediate effect 3. **Division vote** - Senators stand to be counted (rare in modern practice)  Question 3: A bill is on Third Reading. Can Senators offer amendments?  **Answer:** Generally no. Third Reading is for final passage vote only. Amendments require special consent (unanimous consent or 2/3 vote to suspend rules), which is rare. Amendments are debated during General Orders (Second Reading).  Question 4: A bill passes Third Reading with 28 votes. How many votes are needed for immediate effect? What happens if immediate effect gets only 24 votes?  **Answer:**  - **26 votes** (2/3 of 38) needed for immediate effect - If only 24 votes: **Immediate effect denied**, but the bill still becomes law - it just takes effect 90 days after the Legislature adjourns instead of immediately upon the Governor's signature  Question 5: What is the difference between "motion to table" and "motion to postpone"?  **Answer:**  - **Motion to table:** Postpones indefinitely (usually kills the bill) - **Motion to postpone:** Delays to specific time (bill will come back)  Question 6: During General Orders, Senator Smith offers Floor Amendment 1 to SB 200. Voice vote: Amendment adopted. Senator Jones offers Floor Amendment 2. Roll call: Yeas 15, Nays 23. What do you code?  **Answer:**  - FA 1 to SB 200: Adopted (voice vote) - FA 2 to SB 200: Defeated (Roll call: Yeas 15, Nays 23) - Code both amendments with their results  Question 7: What does "motion to reconsider" do?  **Answer:** Motion to reconsider brings back a vote that already happened, nullifying the previous vote so a new vote can be taken. It must usually be made the same day or next session day.  Question 8: The House passes a Senate bill with amendments. What are the Senate's options?  **Answer:**  1. **Concur** - Accept House amendments (requires 20 votes) 2. **Non-concur** - Reject House amendments (usually leads to conference committee)  Question 9: What is a quorum, and why does it matter?  **Answer:** A quorum is the minimum number of Senators who must be present for the Senate to conduct business. Quorum is 20 of 38 (majority). Without a quorum, the Senate cannot vote on bills or take official action.  Question 10: What is a point of order?  **Answer:** A point of order is when a Senator believes Senate rules are being violated. The Senator rises and states the point of order, and the President rules on whether the objection is valid. The President's ruling can be appealed to the full Senate.  Question 11: True or False: Voice votes provide a public record of how each Senator voted.  **Answer:** False. Voice votes do NOT provide individual voting records - only the overall outcome (carried or failed). Roll call votes provide individual voting records.  Question 12: What votes are always roll calls (not voice votes)?  **Answer:**  - Third Reading passage votes - Immediate effect votes - Veto overrides These always require recorded roll call votes.

docs.title: Practice Coding Exercise
docs.text:
You're a Bill Clerk coding floor proceedings. Here's what you hear:

"Senate Bill 445 is before the Senate on General Orders. Senator Williams explains the bill. Senator Jackson offers Floor Amendment 1 to Senate Bill 445. Voice vote. Amendment adopted. Senator Lee offers Floor Amendment 2. Debate ensues. Senator Davis requests a roll call. Roll call: Yeas 12, Nays 26, Excused 0, Not Voting 0. Floor Amendment 2 defeated. Senator Williams moves the bill be advanced to Third Reading. Voice vote. Motion carried."

[Next session day, after 5 days pass]

"Third Reading of Senate Bill 445. The question being on passage of the bill. The Secretary will call the roll. Roll call: Yeas 22, Nays 16, Excused 0, Not Voting 0. The bill passed. Senator Williams moves immediate effect. The question being on immediate effect. The Secretary will call the roll. Roll call: Yeas 28, Nays 10, Excused 0, Not Voting 0. Immediate effect is granted."

What should you have coded? **General Orders Actions:** - SB 445 on General Orders - FA 1 offered by Sen. Jackson: Adopted (voice vote) - FA 2 offered by Sen. Lee: Defeated (Roll call: 12-26) - Motion to advance to Third Reading: Carried (voice vote) **Third Reading Actions:** - SB 445 Third Reading - Passage vote: PASSED (Roll call: 22-16) - Immediate effect vote: GRANTED (Roll call: 28-10) **Next Step:** Bill sent to House

docs.title: Notes for Instructor Q&A
docs.text:
Q: What if I miss an amendment number? A: Ask for clarification immediately or check with your supervisor. Floor amendments are numbered sequentially per bill, so if you miss one, count back through the proceedings.

Q: How fast does the floor move? A: Varies wildly. Some days, dozens of bills pass quickly with no debate. Other days, one controversial bill takes hours. You must be ready for both.

Q: What if I can't hear the vote count? A: Flag it immediately. In modern chambers, vote counts are displayed electronically. Never guess - verify with official count.

Q: Can voice votes be challenged? A: Yes. Any Senator can request a roll call or division vote if they believe the voice vote result was wrong.

Q: What's the difference between "Excused" and "Not Voting"? A: Excused = Absent with permission (illness, official duty). Not Voting = Present but chose not to vote (rare, sometimes due to conflict of interest).

docs.title: Key Takeaways
docs.text: ✅ General Orders is the debate and amendment stage (less formal) ✅ Third Reading is the final passage vote (very formal) ✅ 20 votes for passage, 26 votes for immediate effect ✅ Roll call votes required for passage and immediate effect ✅ Voice votes common for amendments and procedural motions ✅ Bill Clerks must listen carefully and code actions in real-time ✅ Know common motions: advance, table, postpone, refer, reconsider, concur ✅ Five-day rule applies between Third Reading placement and final vote

docs.title: Why Terminology Matters
docs.text:
Legislative proceedings use precise, sometimes archaic language. As a Bill Clerk, you must:

  • Understand what you're hearing in real-time
  • Code accurately using proper terminology
  • Communicate clearly with colleagues and supervisors
  • Avoid errors from misunderstanding terms

This module is your dictionary for the legislative world.

docs.title: Bill
docs.text: Definition: Proposed law introduced in the Legislature Usage: "Senate Bill 234" or "SB 234" Key Point: Not yet law - just a proposal

docs.title: SB / HB
docs.text:
Definition:

  • SB = Senate Bill (originates in Senate)
  • HB = House Bill (originates in House)

Usage: "SB 445" or "House Bill 1022" Key Point: Number tells you which chamber it started in

docs.title: Act / Public Act (PA)
docs.text: Definition: Bill that has passed both chambers and been signed into law by Governor Usage: "Public Act 85 of 2026" or "PA 85 of 2026" Key Point: This is an actual law, no longer just a bill

docs.title: Resolution
docs.text:
Definition: Legislative measure that doesn't have force of law Types:

  • Concurrent Resolution (SCR/HCR): Both chambers must adopt
  • Joint Resolution (SJR/HJR): Proposes constitutional amendment
  • Simple Resolution (SR/HR): One chamber only, ceremonial or procedural

Usage: "Senate Resolution 45" or "SR 45" Key Point: Resolutions ≠ bills. They don't become Public Acts.

docs.title: Statute
docs.text: Definition: Law that's already on the books (previously enacted) Usage: "This bill amends Michigan Compiled Law (MCL) 380.1311" Key Point: Bills amend or create statutes

docs.title: Legislation
docs.text: Definition: General term for bills, resolutions, and other legislative measures Usage: "The Senator is working on legislation about education"

docs.title: Sponsor
docs.text: Definition: Senator who introduces and advocates for a bill Usage: "Senator Martinez is the sponsor of SB 567" Key Point: Primary author and champion of the bill

docs.title: Co-sponsor
docs.text: Definition: Senator who adds their name in support of bill (but didn't introduce it) Usage: "Senators Lee, Davis, and Johnson are co-sponsors" Key Point: Shows additional support but sponsor is still the lead

docs.title: Session
docs.text:
Definition:

  • Session (annual): Two-year legislative term (2025-2026 session)
  • Session day: A day when Legislature meets
  • Legislative session: Period when Legislature is in session vs. adjourned

Usage: "The Senate is in session" or "The 2025-2026 session"

docs.title: Introduced
docs.text: Definition: Bill filed and given a number (First Reading) Status: Just starting the process Bill Clerk Code: Record introduction date, sponsor, bill number

docs.title: Referred
docs.text: Definition: Bill assigned to committee by President of Senate Status: In committee queue Bill Clerk Code: Note which committee receives bill

docs.title: Reported
docs.text: Definition: Committee has acted on bill and sent it back to full Senate Status: Moving forward (unless reported without recommendation) Bill Clerk Code: Record committee action and recommendation

docs.title: General Orders / Second Reading
docs.text: Definition: Bill is on calendar for debate and amendments Status: Amendment stage Bill Clerk Code: Track amendments and votes

docs.title: Third Reading
docs.text: Definition: Bill is on calendar for final passage vote Status: Five-day rule applies; awaiting final vote Bill Clerk Code: Monitor for final vote (after 5 days)

docs.title: Passed
docs.text: Definition: Bill received required number of votes for passage (20+ in Senate) Status: Moves to next chamber or Governor Bill Clerk Code: Record vote totals and result

docs.title: Defeated / Failed
docs.text: Definition: Bill did not receive enough votes for passage Status: Bill is dead (unless reconsidered) Bill Clerk Code: Record vote totals and failed status

docs.title: Amended
docs.text: Definition: Bill has been changed from original version Status: Modified text Bill Clerk Code: Track each amendment adopted

docs.title: Enrolled
docs.text: Definition: Bill passed both chambers and officially prepared for Governor Status: Being sent to Governor Bill Clerk Code: Note enrolled status and date sent to Governor

docs.title: Signed / Enacted
docs.text: Definition: Governor signed bill into law Status: Now a Public Act Bill Clerk Code: Record PA number and effective date

docs.title: Vetoed
docs.text: Definition: Governor rejected bill Status: Returned to Legislature; can attempt override Bill Clerk Code: Record veto date and message

docs.title: Tabled
docs.text: Definition: Bill postponed indefinitely Status: Usually means bill is dead Bill Clerk Code: Note motion to table and vote result

docs.title: Discharged
docs.text: Definition: Bill removed from committee by vote of full Senate Status: Bypasses committee Bill Clerk Code: Record discharge motion and vote

docs.title: Reported with Recommendation "Do Pass"
docs.text: Definition: Committee approves bill as written What happens: Bill goes to General Orders

docs.title: Reported with Recommendation "Do Pass as Amended"
docs.text: Definition: Committee made changes and approves amended version What happens: Bill with committee amendments goes to General Orders

docs.title: Reported with Committee Substitute
docs.text: Definition: Committee rewrote significant portions What happens: Substitute version goes to General Orders

docs.title: Referred to Another Committee
docs.text: Definition: Committee sends bill to different committee What happens: Bill goes to other committee (common: policy → Appropriations)

docs.title: Postponed
docs.text: Definition: Committee delayed decision What happens: Bill stays in committee, may come back (or may die)

docs.title: No Action / No Report
docs.text: Definition: Committee never voted or voted down bill What happens: Bill dies in committee

docs.title: Advanced to Third Reading
docs.text: Definition: Bill moved from General Orders to Third Reading calendar What happens: Five-day rule begins; bill awaits final vote

docs.title: Laid Over
docs.text: Definition: Debate postponed to another day What happens: Bill stays on same calendar, will be called again

docs.title: Placed on Order of General Orders
docs.text: Definition: Bill moved to General Orders calendar (after committee report) What happens: Bill awaits debate and amendments

docs.title: Motion Carried
docs.text: Definition: Vote on motion succeeded What happens: Depends on motion (advance bill, adopt amendment, etc.)

docs.title: Motion Failed / Lost
docs.text: Definition: Vote on motion did not succeed What happens: Motion rejected, no action taken

docs.title: Amendment Adopted
docs.text: Definition: Senate voted to accept amendment What happens: Bill text is changed per amendment

docs.title: Amendment Defeated
docs.text: Definition: Senate voted to reject amendment What happens: Bill text remains unchanged

docs.title: Immediate Effect Granted
docs.text: Definition: Bill received 26+ votes for immediate effect What happens: Law takes effect when Governor signs (not 90 days later)

docs.title: Immediate Effect Denied
docs.text: Definition: Bill received fewer than 26 votes for immediate effect What happens: Law still becomes law but takes effect 90 days after session ends

docs.title: Yeas / Ayes
docs.text: Definition: "Yes" votes Usage: "Yeas 28" or "The ayes have it"

docs.title: Nays / Noes
docs.text: Definition: "No" votes Usage: "Nays 10" or "The noes have it"

docs.title: Roll Call
docs.text: Definition: Individual vote of each Senator recorded Usage: "The Secretary will call the roll" When: Required for passage votes, immediate effect, overrides

docs.title: Voice Vote
docs.text: Definition: Senators say "aye" or "no" collectively, no individual record Usage: "All in favor say 'aye.' All opposed say 'no.'" When: Procedural motions, amendments (unless roll call requested)

docs.title: Division
docs.text: Definition: Senators stand to be counted (rare) Usage: "The President orders a division" When: Unclear voice vote

docs.title: Quorum
docs.text: Definition: Minimum number of members required to conduct business (20 of 38) Usage: "I suggest the absence of a quorum" When: Ensures enough members present to vote

docs.title: Excused
docs.text: Definition: Absent with permission (illness, official duty) Usage: "Yeas 25, Nays 12, Excused 1, Not Voting 0" Impact: Not counted in vote total

docs.title: Not Voting
docs.text: Definition: Present but chose not to vote Usage: "Yeas 24, Nays 13, Excused 0, Not Voting 1" Impact: Rare; sometimes due to conflict of interest

docs.title: Unanimous Consent
docs.text: Definition: Agreement without formal vote (no objections) Usage: "Without objection, so ordered" When: Routine or non-controversial actions

docs.title: Majority
docs.text: Definition: More than half Usage: "A majority of 20 votes required" In Senate: 20 of 38 for most actions

docs.title: Two-Thirds (2/3)
docs.text: Definition: 66.7% of members Usage: "Two-thirds vote required" In Senate: 26 of 38 for immediate effect, veto override, some rule suspensions

docs.title: President of the Senate
docs.text: Definition: Lt. Governor presiding over Senate Role: Runs sessions, recognizes speakers; only substantive power is casting tie-breaking votes

docs.title: President Pro Tempore (Pro Tem)
docs.text: Definition: Senator who presides when Lt. Governor absent Role: Backup presiding officer

docs.title: Majority Leader
docs.text: Definition: Leader of party with most seats Role: Controls agenda, schedules votes, Controls all committee referrals; most powerful position

docs.title: Minority Leader
docs.text: Definition: Leader of party with fewer seats Role: Leads opposition party

docs.title: Floor Leader
docs.text: Definition: Assists party leader with floor operations Role: Manages day-to-day floor proceedings

docs.title: Whip
docs.text: Definition: Assistant leader who counts votes and ensures attendance Role: Party vote counter and enforcer

docs.title: Chair / Committee Chair
docs.text: Definition: Senator who leads a committee Role: Sets committee agenda, decides which bills get hearings

docs.title: Ranking Member
docs.text: Definition: Most senior minority party member on committee Role: Leads minority on committee

docs.title: Conferee
docs.text: Definition: Senator appointed to conference committee Role: Negotiates compromise between Senate and House versions

docs.title: Clerk / Bill Clerk
docs.text: Definition: Staff member who records legislative actions Role: Code bills, track amendments, record votes (that's you!)

docs.title: Session Day
docs.text: Definition: Day when Legislature meets Not: Every calendar day; Legislature doesn't meet every day

docs.title: Sine Die
docs.text: Definition: Final adjournment of legislative session (Latin: "without day") Usage: "The Legislature adjourned sine die on December 20" Impact: Bills don't carry over; must be reintroduced in new session

docs.title: Lame Duck
docs.text: Definition: Period between November election and end of year (sine die) Context: Some legislators defeated/retiring but still serving Impact: Often busy period with controversial legislation

docs.title: Recess
docs.text: Definition: Temporary break in session (summer recess, holiday recess) Difference from Adjournment: Recess is break within session; adjournment ends session

docs.title: Adjournment
docs.text: Definition: End of session day Usage: "The Senate stands adjourned until tomorrow at 10 a.m."

docs.title: Reconvene
docs.text: Definition: Legislature returns after recess or adjournment Usage: "The Senate will reconvene on January 15"

docs.title: Fiscal Year (FY)
docs.text: Definition: State's budget year (Michigan: October 1 - September 30) Usage: "FY 2026" runs October 1, 2025 - September 30, 2026

docs.title: General Fund (GF)
docs.text: Definition: Primary state budget funded by state taxes Contrast: Special funds (gas tax, lottery, etc.)

docs.title: Appropriation
docs.text: Definition: Legislative authorization to spend money Usage: "This bill appropriates $50 million for road repairs"

docs.title: Fiscal Note / Fiscal Impact
docs.text: Definition: Estimate of bill's cost or revenue effect Prepared by: Nonpartisan fiscal analysts Impact: Bills with significant fiscal impact go to Appropriations Committee

docs.title: Boilerplate
docs.text: Definition: Language in appropriations bills that sets conditions on spending Usage: "The boilerplate prohibits using these funds for..."

docs.title: Tie Vote
docs.text: Definition: Equal votes on both sides In Senate: Lt. Governor (President) can vote to break tie Result: If tie not broken, motion fails

docs.title: Override
docs.text: Definition: Legislature passes bill over Governor's veto Requirement: 2/3 vote in both chambers (26 in Senate, 74 in House)

docs.title: Pocket Veto
docs.text: Definition: Bill dies when Governor takes no action after Legislature adjourns Context: If Legislature in session, bill becomes law after 14 days without signature

docs.title: Concurrence
docs.text: Definition: One chamber agreeing to other chamber's amendments Usage: "The Senate concurred in the House amendments"

docs.title: Non-Concurrence
docs.text: Definition: One chamber rejecting other chamber's amendments Usage: "The Senate non-concurred in the House amendments"

docs.title: Conference Committee
docs.text: Definition: Joint Senate-House committee to resolve differences Members: 3 Senators, 3 Representatives Product: Conference Report (compromise version)

docs.title: Conference Report
docs.text: Definition: Compromise bill from conference committee Requirement: Both chambers must approve without amendments

docs.title: Substitute Bill
docs.text: Definition: Complete rewrite of bill (committee or floor) Impact: Original bill replaced with new version

docs.title: Germaneness
docs.text: Definition: Requirement that amendments relate to bill's subject Purpose: Prevent unrelated "riders" Enforcement: President rules whether amendment is germane

docs.title: Rider
docs.text: Definition: Unrelated provision added to bill Context: Sometimes controversial policy attached to "must-pass" bill

docs.title: Privilege
docs.text: Definition: Parliamentary status allowing priority action Usage: "A question of privilege" (pertains to member's rights or chamber's integrity)

docs.title: Practice: Match the Term
docs.text: Match each scenario with the correct term:

docs.title: Scenario 1:
docs.text:
The Governor signs SB 445. It is now _.

Answer **Public Act (PA)** or **Enacted Law**

docs.title: Scenario 2:
docs.text:
The Senate votes on SB 234. Result: Yeas 18, Nays 20. The bill is _.

Answer **Defeated** or **Failed** (needs 20 votes to pass)

docs.title: Scenario 3:
docs.text:
Senator Martinez adds her name to support SB 567, which was introduced by Senator Johnson. She is a _.

Answer **Co-sponsor** (Johnson is the sponsor)

docs.title: Scenario 4:
docs.text:
A bill passes 28-10 but immediate effect vote is 24-14. Immediate effect is _.

Answer **Denied** (needs 26 votes; only got 24)

docs.title: Scenario 5:
docs.text:
The Education Committee sends SB 678 to the Appropriations Committee. This is called _.

Answer **Referred to Another Committee** or **Multiple Referral**

docs.title: Scenario 6:
docs.text:
Floor Amendment 2 to SB 890 receives Yeas 21, Nays 17. The amendment is _.

Answer **Adopted** or **Adopted by Voice Vote** (if voice vote) or **Adopted by Roll Call** (if roll call)

docs.title: Scenario 7:
docs.text:
The Senate votes to accept the House's changes to SB 345. The Senate _ in the House amendments.

Answer **Concurred** or **Concurs**

docs.title: Scenario 8:
docs.text:
It's December 15. The Legislature will end for the year on December 31 and not return until January. This period is called _.

Answer **Lame Duck** session

docs.title: Self-Check Quiz
docs.text: Question 1: What's the difference between a bill and a Public Act?  **Answer:** A **bill** is a proposed law that has not yet been enacted. A **Public Act (PA)** is a bill that has passed both chambers and been signed into law by the Governor. Bills are proposals; Public Acts are actual laws.   Question 2: What does "SB 234" tell you?  **Answer:** SB = Senate Bill, meaning this bill originated in the Michigan Senate (not the House). The number 234 is the sequential number assigned when the bill was introduced.   Question 3: What is the difference between "sponsor" and "co-sponsor"?  **Answer:** The **sponsor** is the Senator who introduces the bill and is its primary author/champion. **Co-sponsors** are other Senators who add their names in support but didn't introduce the bill.   Question 4: A bill is "referred to committee." What does that mean?  **Answer:** The bill has been assigned to a committee for review. The committee will decide whether to hold hearings, make amendments, and report the bill back to the full Senate.   Question 5: What is "General Orders"?  **Answer:** General Orders (also called Committee of the Whole or Second Reading) is the stage where the full Senate debates bills and considers amendments. It's less formal than Third Reading.   Question 6: What does it mean when a bill is "enrolled"?  **Answer:** The bill has passed both the Senate and House in identical form and is being officially prepared to send to the Governor for signature.   Question 7: What's the difference between "Yeas" and "Nays"?  **Answer:** **Yeas** (or Ayes) are "yes" votes. **Nays** (or Noes) are "no" votes.   Question 8: What is a quorum and why does it matter?  **Answer:** A **quorum** is the minimum number of Senators required to conduct business (20 of 38 in Michigan Senate). Without a quorum present, the Senate cannot vote on bills or take official actions.   Question 9: What does "immediate effect denied" mean?  **Answer:** The bill did not receive enough votes (26 required) for immediate effect. The bill can still become law, but it will take effect 90 days after the legislative session ends instead of immediately when the Governor signs it.   Question 10: What is the difference between "tabled" and "postponed"?  **Answer:** **Tabled** means postponed indefinitely (usually kills the bill - it rarely comes back). **Postponed** means delayed to a specific time (the bill will be reconsidered).   Question 11: What does "sine die" mean?  **Answer:** **Sine die** (Latin: "without day") means final adjournment of the legislative session for the year. Bills that haven't passed by sine die must be reintroduced in the next session.   Question 12: The Senate "concurs" in House amendments. What happens next?  **Answer:** The bill has passed both chambers in identical form and is sent to the Governor for signature.

docs.title: Notes for Instructor Q&A
docs.text:
Q: Do I need to memorize all these terms? A: Core terms (bill, SB, PA, passed, referred, GO, Third Reading, IE, concur) are essential. Others you'll learn through repetition. Focus on terms you'll hear most often during sessions.

Q: What if I hear a term I don't recognize during a live session? A: Flag it and ask your supervisor after the immediate action is coded. Don't let unfamiliar terms stop you from coding what you do understand.

Q: Are there regional variations in terminology? A: Some terms vary between states, but within Michigan, terminology is standardized. Always use Michigan's official terms.

Q: How can I practice terminology? A: Read the Senate Journal, watch archived sessions, and complete the practice scenarios in this course. Repetition is key.

docs.title: Key Takeaways
docs.text: ✅ Legislative language is precise and formal ✅ Bill = proposed law; PA = enacted law ✅ SB = Senate Bill; HB = House Bill ✅ Know bill status terms: introduced, referred, reported, passed, enrolled ✅ Understand voting terms: Yeas, Nays, roll call, voice vote, quorum ✅ Master floor action terms: General Orders, Third Reading, concur, immediate effect ✅ Learn common abbreviations: FA, GO, IE, PA, MCL ✅ Practice hearing and using terms in context

docs.title: Learning Objectives
docs.text: By the end of this module, you will be able to: - Explain why both chambers must pass identical bills - Describe how bills move between Senate and House - Understand the concurrence process - Explain Conference Committees and their role - Identify key differences between Senate and House procedures - Track inter-chamber bill movement as a Bill Clerk

docs.title: Why Two Chambers?
docs.text: Michigan, like most states and the U.S. Congress, has a bicameral (two-chamber) legislature: - Michigan Senate: 38 members, 4-year terms - Michigan House: 110 members, 2-year terms

docs.title: The Iron Rule:
docs.text:
Both chambers must pass IDENTICAL versions of a bill before it can go to the Governor.

This means: - If Senate passes SB 100 and sends it to House - If House amends SB 100 before passing it - The Senate must approve those House amendments - Or the chambers must negotiate until they agree on identical text

No exceptions. This is constitutionally required.

docs.title: Starting Point: Bill Can Originate in Either Chamber
docs.text:
• Senate Bill (SB): Starts in Senate
  • House Bill (HB): Starts in House

For this module, we'll focus on Senate bills going to the House (since you'll be working in the Senate).

docs.title: The Standard Path: Senate Bill to House
Step 1: Senate Passes Bill
docs.text:
Senate completes full process: 1. Introduction (First Reading) 2. Committee referral and action 3. General Orders (Second Reading) 4. Third Reading (passage with 20+ votes) 5. Immediate effect vote (if applicable)

Result: Bill passed by Senate

docs.title: Step 2: Bill Sent to House
docs.text:
What happens: - Bill transmitted to House with message: "The Senate has passed Senate Bill X" - House receives bill and begins its own process - Completely independent review: House doesn't rubber-stamp Senate work

Bill Clerk Action (Senate side): Code "sent to House" with date

docs.title: Step 3: House Process
docs.text:
House goes through same stages as Senate (but with House-specific procedures): 1. First Reading: Bill introduced in House 2. Committee Referral: House leadership assigns to House committee 3. Committee Action: House committee reviews (may be different recommendation than Senate committee) 4. General Orders: House Committee of the Whole debates and amends 5. Third Reading: House final passage vote (needs 56 of 110 votes)

Timeline: Can take days, weeks, or months. Some bills never get House hearings.

docs.title: Outcome A: House Passes Bill Unchanged ✅
docs.text:
What happens: - House passes Senate bill exactly as received - No amendments - Identical versions passed by both chambers

Next step: Bill goes directly to Governor

Bill Clerk Action: Code "House passed SB X" (no amendments)

This is the simplest path!

docs.title: Outcome B: House Passes Bill with Amendments 🔄
docs.text:
What happens: - House changes bill (adds, deletes, or modifies language) - House passes amended version - Bill returns to Senate with House amendments

Next step: Senate must decide whether to accept House amendments (see Concurrence section below)

Bill Clerk Action: Code "House passed SB X with amendments"

This is very common. Often leads to negotiations.

docs.title: Outcome C: House Defeats Bill or Takes No Action ❌
docs.text:
What happens: - House committee never reports bill, or - House committee reports "do not pass," or - House votes down bill on floor, or - House never acts before session ends

Result: Bill dies

Next step: None (bill is dead)

Bill Clerk Action: Code "House took no action" or "House defeated SB X"

Reality check: Many Senate bills die in House, and vice versa. Each chamber protects its prerogatives.

docs.title: What is Concurrence?
docs.text: Concurrence is when one chamber votes to accept the other chamber's amendments.

docs.title: When It Happens:
docs.text: After House passes Senate bill with amendments, amended bill returns to Senate. Senate must vote on whether to concur (agree) or non-concur (disagree).

docs.title: Option 1: Senate Concurs (Accepts House Amendments)
docs.text:
Process: 1. Presiding officer announces: "Message from the House. The House has passed Senate Bill X with amendments." 2. House amendments read or explained 3. Motion made: "I move the Senate concur in the House amendments to Senate Bill X" 4. Debate (if any) 5. Vote (roll call usually required) 6. If 20+ votes: Senate concurs

Result: - Both chambers have now passed identical version - Bill goes to Governor - Process complete

Bill Clerk Action: Code "Senate concurred in House amendments, Yeas [#], Nays [#]"

Example: "The question being on concurrence in the House amendments to Senate Bill 445. Roll call: Yeas 24, Nays 14. The Senate concurs in the House amendments."

docs.title: Option 2: Senate Non-Concurs (Rejects House Amendments)
docs.text:
Process: 1. House amendments announced 2. Motion made: "I move the Senate non-concur in the House amendments to Senate Bill X" 3. Vote 4. If majority votes to non-concur: Senate non-concurs

Result: - Senate and House still disagree - Bill stuck (different versions in each chamber) - Usually leads to Conference Committee request

Bill Clerk Action: Code "Senate non-concurred in House amendments"

Why Senate might non-concur: - House amendments change policy in unacceptable way - House amendments too expensive - House amendments weaken bill - Political disagreement

Example: "The question being on concurrence in the House amendments to Senate Bill 567. The Senate non-concurs. Senator Martinez moves that a Conference Committee be appointed."

docs.title: What is a Conference Committee?
docs.text: A Conference Committee is a joint Senate-House committee created to negotiate a compromise when the chambers pass different versions of a bill.

docs.title: Composition:
docs.text:
• 3 Senators (appointed by Senate Majority Leader or President)
  • 3 Representatives (appointed by House Speaker)
  • Usually includes bill sponsors and senior members
  • Typically reflects party balance (e.g., 2 majority, 1 minority from each chamber)

docs.title: 1. Appointment
docs.text:
• Senate non-concurs and requests conference committee
  • Senate appoints 3 conferees
  • House agrees and appoints 3 conferees
  • 6-member committee formed

Bill Clerk Action: Code "Conference Committee requested" and names of Senate conferees

docs.title: 2. Negotiation
docs.text:
• 6 members meet privately
  • Negotiate compromise between Senate and House versions
  • Can take hours, days, or weeks
  • No public hearings (closed-door negotiations)
  • Try to find middle ground both chambers will accept

docs.title: 3. Conference Report
docs.text:
• Committee produces Conference Report - compromise version of bill
  • Report explains changes made
  • Conference Report must be signed by majority of conferees from each chamber (2 of 3 Senators, 2 of 3 Representatives)

docs.title: 4. Both Chambers Vote
docs.text:
• Conference Report sent to both Senate and House
  • Each chamber votes up or down on Conference Report
  • No amendments allowed - must accept or reject as written
  • Requires majority in each chamber (20 in Senate, 56 in House)

Possible outcomes:

Both chambers adopt Conference Report ✅ - Bill has now passed both chambers in identical form (the Conference Report version) - Bill goes to Governor - Success!

One or both chambers reject Conference Report ❌ - Bill fails (or new conference committee appointed) - Rare but happens

Bill Clerk Action: Code Senate vote on Conference Report: "Senate adopted Conference Report on SB X, Yeas [#], Nays [#]"

docs.title: Real-World Example: Bill Ping-Pong
docs.text:
Senate Bill 789: School Safety Funding

Act 1: Senate Action - Original Senate version: $100 million for school security equipment, distributed equally to all districts - Senate passes SB 789: Yeas 30, Nays 8 - Immediate effect granted - Sent to House

Act 2: House Changes - House Education Committee amends bill: - Reduces funding to $75 million - Changes distribution formula (based on enrollment, not equal) - Adds reporting requirements for districts - House passes SB 789 with amendments: Yeas 68, Nays 42 - Bill returns to Senate with House amendments

Act 3: Senate Decision Point - Senate leadership reviews House amendments - Concerns: - Less money ($75M vs $100M) - Distribution formula hurts rural districts - Positives: - $75M better than nothing - Bill moves forward - Decision: Try to negotiate better deal

Act 4: Non-Concurrence and Conference Committee - Senate votes to non-concur in House amendments: Yeas 25, Nays 13 - Senate requests Conference Committee - Senate conferees appointed: Senators Martinez (sponsor), Lee (Education Chair), Johnson (Minority) - House conferees appointed: Reps. Brown (sponsor), Davis (Education Chair), Wilson (Minority)

Act 5: Conference Negotiations - 6 conferees meet over 2 days - Compromise reached: - $85 million (split the difference) - Hybrid distribution formula: 50% equal, 50% enrollment-based (helps both rural and urban) - Simplified reporting requirements (less burdensome than House version)

Act 6: Conference Report - Conference Report drafted and signed by 5 of 6 conferees (1 House member opposed) - Report sent to both chambers

Act 7: Both Chambers Vote - Senate vote on Conference Report: Yeas 28, Nays 10 ✅ - House vote on Conference Report: Yeas 71, Nays 39 ✅ - Both chambers adopted!

Act 8: To Governor - Bill enrolled and sent to Governor - Governor signs bill - Becomes PA 124 of 2026 - Takes effect immediately (IE was granted originally)

Total time: 4 months from Senate passage to enactment

Bill Clerk tracked: Every step from Senate passage to House message to non-concurrence to Conference Report to final adoption

docs.title: Key Differences Between Senate and House
docs.text: As a Senate Bill Clerk, you'll primarily code Senate actions, but understanding House differences helps you anticipate what happens when Senate bills go to House:

docs.title: Structural Differences:
docs.text: Feature Senate House Size 38 members 110 members Districts ~260,000 constituents ~90,000 constituents Terms 4 years 2 years Presiding Officer Lt. Governor (President of Senate) Speaker of the House (elected Representative) Votes for Passage 20 (majority of 38) 56 (majority of 110) Votes for Immediate Effect 26 (2/3 of 38) 74 (2/3 of 110)

docs.title: Procedural Differences:
docs.text: Feature Senate House Formality More formal, slower pace Less formal, faster pace Debate More leisurely More restricted time Committees 17 standing committees ~20 standing committees (similar names) Seniority More emphasis on seniority Less emphasis on seniority Party Control Leadership has strong control Leadership has very strong control

docs.title: Cultural Differences:
docs.text:
Senate: - Smaller, more collegial - Senators know each other well - Longer terms = less electoral pressure - "Upper chamber" prestige - More deliberative

House: - Larger, more formal rules needed - Representatives may not know all colleagues - 2-year terms = constant campaigning - More responsive to immediate constituent concerns - Faster-paced

Impact on bills: - House may move faster on some bills - Senate may be more deliberative - Each chamber protects its prerogatives (doesn't like being told what to do) - Conference committees are where institutional pride meets compromise

docs.title: Joint Rules:
docs.text: Some rules govern both chambers: - How messages are sent between chambers - Conference committee procedures - Joint sessions (e.g., Governor's State of the State address) - Counting electoral votes

docs.title: Messages Between Chambers:
docs.text:
Formal communications: - "Message from the House: The House has passed Senate Bill X" - "Message from the Senate: The Senate requests a Conference Committee" - Messages read on floor and recorded in Journal

Bill Clerk Note: Code when messages are received and Senate's response

docs.title: Common Reasons Bills Fail Between Chambers
docs.text: Even if a bill passes one chamber, it may fail in the other:

docs.title: 1. Policy Disagreements
docs.text:
• Chambers have different priorities
  • Party control differs (e.g., Senate majority vs. House majority)

docs.title: 2. Turf Wars
docs.text:
• House doesn't like Senate telling it what to do (and vice versa)
  • Chamber pride and institutional prerogatives

docs.title: 3. Time Constraints
docs.text:
• Bill passes Senate late in session
  • House runs out of time to act

docs.title: 4. Committee Chair Opposition
docs.text:
• House committee chair opposes bill
  • Never schedules hearing

docs.title: 5. Leadership Priorities
docs.text:
• House leadership focuses on different issues
  • Senate bill not a priority

docs.title: 6. Political Maneuvering
docs.text:
• Bill used as leverage for other negotiations
  • Held hostage for unrelated compromises

Reality: Only a fraction of bills that pass one chamber pass the other. The bicameral system is a high bar.

docs.title: Self-Check Quiz
docs.text: Question 1: Why must both chambers pass identical versions of a bill?  **Answer:** This is constitutionally required. Michigan's bicameral system requires both the Senate (38 members) and House (110 members) to pass exactly the same version of a bill before it can be sent to the Governor. This ensures thorough review and broader consensus.  Question 2: The House passes a Senate bill with amendments. What are the Senate's two main options?  **Answer:**  1. **Concur** - Accept the House amendments (requires 20 votes); bill goes to Governor 2. **Non-concur** - Reject the House amendments; typically leads to requesting a Conference Committee  Question 3: What is a Conference Committee and who serves on it?  **Answer:** A Conference Committee is a joint Senate-House committee created to negotiate a compromise when chambers pass different versions of a bill. It consists of 3 Senators and 3 Representatives appointed by their respective leaders.  Question 4: Can legislators amend a Conference Report?  **Answer:** No. Conference Reports must be voted up or down as written. No amendments are allowed. Each chamber must accept or reject the entire compromise.  Question 5: Senate passes SB 234. House passes SB 234 unchanged. What happens next?  **Answer:** The bill goes directly to the Governor because both chambers have passed identical versions. No concurrence vote or conference committee needed.  Question 6: How many votes are needed for the Senate to concur in House amendments?  **Answer:** 20 votes (majority of 38 Senators), same as for passage of a bill.  Question 7: What's the difference between Senate and House in terms of size and terms?  **Answer:**  - **Senate:** 38 members, 4-year terms - **House:** 110 members, 2-year terms  Question 8: True or False: If the Senate passes a bill, the House is required to give it a hearing and vote on it.  **Answer:** False. The House has complete independence. The House committee chair can decline to schedule a hearing, effectively killing the bill. Each chamber controls its own agenda.  Question 9: A Conference Committee produces a report. Senate adopts it 25-13, but House rejects it 48-62. What happens?  **Answer:** The bill fails (at least temporarily). Both chambers must adopt the Conference Report for the bill to proceed. The chambers could appoint a new conference committee to try again, or the bill dies.  Question 10: Why might the Senate non-concur in House amendments even if the Senate wants the bill to pass?  **Answer:** The Senate may believe the House amendments are unacceptable (change policy too much, reduce funding, add problematic provisions, etc.) and want to negotiate a better compromise through a Conference Committee rather than accepting the House version.

docs.title: Notes for Instructor Q&A
docs.text:
Q: How often do Conference Committees happen? A: Fairly common for significant bills. Maybe 10-20% of major bills that pass both chambers require conference committees. Minor bills often pass one chamber and die in the other.

Q: What if Conference Committee negotiations fail? A: The bill dies, or a new conference committee is appointed. Sometimes chambers just give up and move on to other priorities.

Q: Can the Senate just force the House to pass a bill? A: No. Each chamber is completely independent. The Senate cannot force House action, and vice versa. This is a key feature of bicameralism.

Q: Why do chambers sometimes play games with each other's bills? A: Politics, institutional pride, leverage for other negotiations. Each chamber protects its prerogatives and sometimes holds bills hostage to gain concessions on other issues.

Q: As a Senate Bill Clerk, do I need to code House actions in detail? A: You code when House messages are received and how Senate responds. You don't code the House's internal process (First Reading, committee, etc.) - just the outcome and Senate's reaction.

docs.title: Key Takeaways
docs.text: ✅ Both chambers must pass identical versions of bills ✅ House can pass Senate bill unchanged, with amendments, or not at all ✅ If House amends Senate bill, Senate votes to concur or non-concur ✅ Non-concurrence typically leads to Conference Committee ✅ Conference Committee: 3 Senators + 3 Representatives negotiate compromise ✅ Conference Report must be adopted by both chambers (no amendments allowed) ✅ Senate has 38 members; House has 110 members ✅ Many bills pass one chamber but die in the other ✅ Bill Clerks track messages from House and Senate's responses

docs.title: Scenario 1: Committee Report
docs.text:
You're a Bill Clerk. The Committee Chair announces:

"Mr. President, the Committee on Transportation and Infrastructure has had under consideration Senate Bill 342, a bill to amend the Michigan Vehicle Code regarding electric vehicle charging stations. The committee reports the bill with the recommendation 'do pass as amended.' The committee amendments change the implementation timeline from 2025 to 2026 and add reporting requirements for charging station operators. The committee also refers the bill to the Committee on Appropriations due to fiscal impact."

docs.title: Questions:
docs.text:
1. What committee reported the bill?
  2. What was the committee's action/recommendation?
  3. What changes did the committee make?
  4. Where does the bill go next?
  5. What should you code?
Answer Key ### Answers: 1. **Committee:** Transportation and Infrastructure 2. **Action:** Reported with recommendation "do pass as amended" 3. **Changes:** Committee made two amendments: - Changed implementation timeline from 2025 to 2026 - Added reporting requirements for charging station operators 4. **Next step:** Bill goes to Appropriations Committee (NOT to General Orders) because of fiscal impact 5. **Code:** - SB 342 - Committee: Transportation and Infrastructure - Action: Reported "do pass as amended" - Committee amendments: Timeline change, reporting requirements added - Referred to: Appropriations Committee ### Key Learning Points: - Bill doesn't go to General Orders yet because of additional committee referral - "Do pass as amended" means committee made changes - Multiple referrals are common (policy committee → Appropriations) - You should note the substance of amendments for context

docs.title: Scenario 2: Floor Amendment on General Orders
docs.text:
You're coding floor proceedings:

President: "Senate Bill 445 is before the Senate on General Orders. The Senator from the 15th District is recognized."

Senator Williams: "Thank you, Mr. President. Senate Bill 445 addresses rural broadband access by providing grants to internet service providers. I ask my colleagues for support."

President: "The Senator from the 22nd District is recognized."

Senator Jackson: "Mr. President, I offer Floor Amendment 1 to Senate Bill 445. This amendment increases the grant cap from $500,000 to $750,000 per provider to better address the infrastructure costs in rural areas."

President: "The amendment has been offered. The question being on the adoption of Floor Amendment 1. All in favor say 'aye.' All opposed say 'no.' In the opinion of the Chair, the ayes have it. The amendment is adopted."

Senator Lee: "Mr. President, I offer Floor Amendment 2 to Senate Bill 445. This amendment adds a reporting requirement for grant recipients to submit annual progress reports."

President: "The amendment has been offered. Senator Davis?"

Senator Davis: "I request a roll call vote, Mr. President."

President: "A roll call has been requested. The question being on the adoption of Floor Amendment 2. The Secretary will call the roll... Roll call: Yeas 15, Nays 23, Excused 0, Not Voting 0. The amendment is defeated."

Senator Williams: "Mr. President, I move that Senate Bill 445 be advanced to Third Reading."

President: "The question being on advancing the bill to Third Reading. All in favor say 'aye.' All opposed say 'no.' In the opinion of the Chair, the ayes have it. The bill is advanced to Third Reading."

docs.title: Questions:
docs.text:
1. What stage is SB 445 in at the beginning?
  2. How many amendments were offered?
  3. What was the result of Floor Amendment 1?
  4. What was the result of Floor Amendment 2?
  5. What happened at the end?
  6. What should you code for this entire sequence?
Answer Key ### Answers: 1. **Stage:** General Orders (Committee of the Whole) 2. **Amendments offered:** Two (FA 1 and FA 2) 3. **FA 1 result:** ADOPTED (voice vote) - increased grant cap from $500K to $750K 4. **FA 2 result:** DEFEATED (roll call: 15-23) - reporting requirement rejected 5. **Final action:** Bill advanced to Third Reading (voice vote) 6. **Complete coding:** **SB 445 - General Orders:** - Sponsor: Senator Williams (15th District) - Subject: Rural broadband grants to ISPs **Amendments:** - FA 1 (Sen. Jackson): Increase grant cap $500K → $750K - Vote: Voice vote - Result: ADOPTED - FA 2 (Sen. Lee): Add annual reporting requirement - Vote: Roll call - Yeas 15, Nays 23, Excused 0, Not Voting 0 - Result: DEFEATED **Motion to Advance:** - Made by: Sen. Williams - Vote: Voice vote - Result: CARRIED - Bill advanced to Third Reading ### Key Learning Points: - General Orders is where amendments happen - Voice votes don't record individual votes (just "ayes have it") - Any Senator can request roll call vote - Roll call shows exact vote count - Bill must be moved to Third Reading (not automatic) - Five-day rule starts when bill placed on Third Reading

docs.title: Scenario 3: Advancing to Third Reading
docs.text:
Senate floor proceedings continue:

President: "The Chair lays before the Senate Senate Bill 567 on General Orders."

Senator Martinez: "Mr. President, Senate Bill 567 reforms the Michigan Business Tax to provide credits for small businesses hiring veterans. The bill was thoroughly reviewed in the Finance Committee and I urge my colleagues to support it."

President: "Is there any discussion? Seeing none, the question is on advancing Senate Bill 567 to Third Reading. All in favor say 'aye.' All opposed say 'no.' In the opinion of the Chair, the ayes have it. Senate Bill 567 is advanced to Third Reading."

docs.title: Questions:
docs.text:
1. What happened in this scenario?
  2. Were any amendments offered?
  3. What is the next step for SB 567?
  4. When can the Senate vote on final passage?
  5. What should you code?
Answer Key ### Answers: 1. **What happened:** SB 567 was on General Orders, no amendments were offered, and it was advanced to Third Reading 2. **Amendments:** None offered (clean advance) 3. **Next step:** Bill placed on Third Reading calendar; five-day rule begins 4. **Final passage vote:** Cannot happen until at least 5 calendar days pass after bill placed on Third Reading 5. **Code:** - SB 567 on General Orders - Sponsor: Sen. Martinez - Subject: Michigan Business Tax credits for hiring veterans - No amendments offered - Motion to advance to Third Reading: CARRIED (voice vote) - Bill advanced to Third Reading - Date placed on Third Reading: [today's date] - Eligible for final vote: [today + 5 calendar days] ### Key Learning Points: - Not all bills are amended on General Orders - Some bills move quickly if non-controversial - Five-day rule is critical - mark the date! - Count 5 CALENDAR days (not session days) - Example: Placed Monday → Eligible Saturday

docs.title: Scenario 4: Third Reading and Final Passage
docs.text:
Five days have passed. Third Reading vote occurs:

President: "The Chair lays before the Senate Senate Bill 567 on Third Reading. The bill has been on Third Reading for five calendar days and is now eligible for final passage. The question being on passage of the bill. The Secretary will call the roll."

Secretary: [Calls roll of all 38 Senators]

President: "Roll call: Yeas 32, Nays 6, Excused 0, Not Voting 0. The bill has passed. Senator Martinez?"

Senator Martinez: "Mr. President, I move immediate effect."

President: "The question being on immediate effect. The Secretary will call the roll."

Secretary: [Calls roll again]

President: "Roll call on immediate effect: Yeas 28, Nays 10, Excused 0, Not Voting 0. Immediate effect is granted. The bill is ordered to the House."

docs.title: Questions:
docs.text:
1. How many votes did the bill receive for passage?
  2. Did the bill pass?
  3. How many votes are needed for passage?
  4. How many votes did immediate effect receive?
  5. Was immediate effect granted?
  6. How many votes are needed for immediate effect?
  7. What happens next?
  8. What should you code?
Answer Key ### Answers: 1. **Passage votes:** 32 Yeas, 6 Nays 2. **Did it pass:** YES (needs 20, got 32) 3. **Votes needed for passage:** 20 (majority of 38) 4. **Immediate effect votes:** 28 Yeas, 10 Nays 5. **IE granted:** YES (needs 26, got 28) 6. **Votes needed for IE:** 26 (2/3 of 38) 7. **Next step:** Bill sent to House for House process 8. **Code:** - SB 567 - Third Reading - Five-day rule satisfied (5 calendar days passed) - Final passage vote: Roll call - Yeas 32, Nays 6, Excused 0, Not Voting 0 - Result: **PASSED** - Immediate effect vote: Roll call - Yeas 28, Nays 10, Excused 0, Not Voting 0 - Result: **IMMEDIATE EFFECT GRANTED** - Status: Sent to House ### Key Learning Points: - Third Reading is always roll call (individual votes recorded) - 20 votes needed for passage - 26 votes needed for immediate effect - Immediate effect is separate vote after passage - Bill can pass but IE can fail (bill still becomes law, just takes effect later) - In this case, both passed - Bill now goes to House for House process

docs.title: Scenario 5: Immediate Effect Denied
docs.text:
Different scenario - Third Reading vote:

President: "Third Reading of Senate Bill 789. The question being on passage of the bill. The Secretary will call the roll."

[Roll call occurs]

President: "Roll call: Yeas 30, Nays 8, Excused 0, Not Voting 0. The bill has passed. Senator Lee?"

Senator Lee: "Mr. President, I move immediate effect."

President: "The question being on immediate effect. The Secretary will call the roll."

[Roll call occurs]

President: "Roll call on immediate effect: Yeas 24, Nays 14, Excused 0, Not Voting 0. Immediate effect is denied. The bill is ordered to the House."

docs.title: Questions:
docs.text:
1. Did SB 789 pass the Senate?
  2. Was immediate effect granted?
  3. What does this mean for when the law takes effect?
  4. Does the bill still go to the House?
  5. What should you code?
Answer Key ### Answers: 1. **Did it pass:** YES - got 30 votes (needs only 20) 2. **IE granted:** NO - got only 24 votes (needs 26) 3. **When law takes effect:** If Governor signs, law will take effect **90 days after the Legislature adjourns for the year** (sine die). Does NOT take effect immediately. 4. **Goes to House:** YES - bill still proceeds normally. IE denial doesn't kill the bill. 5. **Code:** - SB 789 - Third Reading - Final passage: PASSED - Yeas 30, Nays 8, Excused 0, Not Voting 0 - Immediate effect: **DENIED** - Yeas 24, Nays 14, Excused 0, Not Voting 0 - (Needed 26, got only 24) - Status: Sent to House - Note: Law will take effect 90 days after sine die (not immediately) ### Key Learning Points: - Bill can pass but immediate effect can fail - This happens fairly often (easier to get 20 than 26) - Bill is NOT killed by IE denial - Bill still goes to House and can become law - Only difference: effective date (immediate vs. 90 days later) - Some Senators vote FOR passage but AGAINST immediate effect (want law but not right away)

docs.title: Scenario 6: House Amendments and Concurrence
docs.text:
House message and Senate response:

President: "The Chair lays before the Senate a message from the House of Representatives. The Secretary will read the message."

Secretary: "Message from the House: Mr. President, the House has passed Senate Bill 567 with amendments. The House amendments are as follows: Amendment 1 changes the small business definition to include businesses with 50 or fewer employees instead of 100. Amendment 2 adds a sunset provision requiring the program to be reauthorized after three years."

President: "The bill is before the Senate for concurrence in the House amendments. The Senator from the 15th District is recognized."

Senator Martinez: "Thank you, Mr. President. I have reviewed the House amendments. While I would have preferred to keep the 100-employee threshold, the 50-employee limit is acceptable and ensures the program targets truly small businesses. The three-year sunset is reasonable. I move the Senate concur in the House amendments to Senate Bill 567."

President: "The question being on concurrence in the House amendments to Senate Bill 567. The Secretary will call the roll."

[Roll call occurs]

President: "Roll call: Yeas 24, Nays 14, Excused 0, Not Voting 0. The Senate concurs in the House amendments. The bill is ordered enrolled and sent to the Governor."

docs.title: Questions:
docs.text:
1. What did the House do to SB 567?
  2. What were the House amendments?
  3. What motion did Senator Martinez make?
  4. What was the vote result?
  5. What happens next?
  6. What should you code?
Answer Key ### Answers: 1. **House action:** House passed SB 567 with amendments (changed the bill) 2. **House amendments:** - Amendment 1: Changed small business definition from 100 employees → 50 employees - Amendment 2: Added 3-year sunset (program must be reauthorized) 3. **Motion:** Senator Martinez moved to **concur** in House amendments 4. **Vote result:** 24-14, Senate CONCURRED (needs 20, got 24) 5. **Next step:** Bill enrolled and sent to Governor (both chambers have now passed identical version) 6. **Code:** - Message from House: House passed SB 567 with amendments - House amendments: 1. Small business definition: 100 employees → 50 employees 2. Added 3-year sunset provision - Senate action: Motion to concur - Vote: Roll call - Yeas 24, Nays 14, Excused 0, Not Voting 0 - Result: **SENATE CONCURRED** - Status: Bill enrolled and sent to Governor ### Key Learning Points: - Concurrence requires 20 votes (simple majority) - When Senate concurs, both chambers have passed identical version - Bill goes straight to Governor (no conference committee needed) - Sponsor may not like House amendments but accept them to move bill forward - Once concurred, Senate is done with bill (now up to Governor)

docs.title: Scenario 7: Non-Concurrence and Conference Committee
docs.text:
Different scenario with House amendments:

President: "The Chair lays before the Senate a message from the House. The House has passed Senate Bill 890 with amendments. The House amendments reduce funding from $100 million to $60 million and change the distribution formula significantly. The Senator from the 8th District?"

Senator Johnson: "Mr. President, I appreciate the House's work on this bill, but the $60 million funding level is insufficient to achieve the bill's goals. The original $100 million was based on careful analysis. Additionally, the House's distribution formula would disadvantage rural areas. I move the Senate non-concur in the House amendments to Senate Bill 890 and request a Conference Committee be appointed."

President: "The question being on non-concurrence in the House amendments. All in favor say 'aye.' All opposed say 'no.' In the opinion of the Chair, the ayes have it. The Senate non-concurs. The motion for a Conference Committee is in order."

Senator Johnson: "I so move, Mr. President."

President: "The motion is made. Without objection, a Conference Committee is requested. The Chair appoints Senators Johnson, Lee, and Davis as conferees. A message will be sent to the House."

docs.title: Questions:
docs.text:
1. What did Senator Johnson move?
  2. Why did he move to non-concur?
  3. What vote was taken on non-concurrence?
  4. What happened after non-concurrence?
  5. Who are the Senate conferees?
  6. What happens next?
  7. What should you code?
Answer Key ### Answers: 1. **Motion:** Senator Johnson moved to **non-concur** in House amendments 2. **Reason:** Funding too low ($60M vs. $100M) and distribution formula disadvantages rural areas 3. **Vote:** Voice vote, Senate non-concurred 4. **After non-concur:** Conference Committee requested and appointed 5. **Senate conferees:** Senators Johnson, Lee, and Davis (3 Senators) 6. **Next steps:** - House will appoint 3 Representatives as conferees - 6-member Conference Committee will negotiate compromise - Committee will produce Conference Report - Both chambers must vote on Conference Report 7. **Code:** - Message from House: House passed SB 890 with amendments - House amendments: - Reduced funding: $100M → $60M - Changed distribution formula - Senate action: Motion to non-concur - Vote: Voice vote - Result: **SENATE NON-CONCURRED** - Conference Committee requested - Senate conferees appointed: Johnson, Lee, Davis - Status: Awaiting House appointment of conferees ### Key Learning Points: - Non-concurrence is appropriate when House amendments are unacceptable - Usually leads to Conference Committee (negotiation) - Senate appoints 3 conferees (usually sponsor + committee chair + minority member) - House will appoint 3 conferees (total 6) - Conference Committee will negotiate compromise - Both chambers must approve Conference Report for bill to proceed - Non-concurrence doesn't kill bill - it's negotiation tactic

docs.title: Scenario 8: Adopting Conference Report
docs.text:
Conference Committee has completed work:

President: "The Chair lays before the Senate the Conference Report on Senate Bill 890. The Senator from the 8th District?"

Senator Johnson: "Thank you, Mr. President. The Conference Committee met several times and produced a compromise. The Conference Report sets funding at $80 million, splitting the difference between the Senate's $100 million and the House's $60 million. The distribution formula uses a hybrid approach that addresses both urban and rural needs. I believe this is a fair compromise that allows the bill to move forward. I move the Senate adopt the Conference Report on Senate Bill 890."

President: "The Senator from the 22nd District?"

Senator Lee: "As a conferee, I support the Conference Report. It's not perfect, but it achieves the bill's core objectives."

President: "The question being on adoption of the Conference Report on Senate Bill 890. The Secretary will call the roll."

[Roll call occurs]

President: "Roll call: Yeas 26, Nays 12, Excused 0, Not Voting 0. The Senate adopts the Conference Report. A message will be sent to the House."

[Next day]

President: "The Chair has received a message from the House. The House has adopted the Conference Report on Senate Bill 890. The bill is ordered enrolled and sent to the Governor."

docs.title: Questions:
docs.text:
1. What did the Conference Committee do?
  2. What was the compromise?
  3. What was the Senate vote on the Conference Report?
  4. What did the House do?
  5. What happens next?
  6. Can either chamber amend the Conference Report?
  7. What should you code?
Answer Key ### Answers: 1. **Conference Committee:** Negotiated compromise between Senate version ($100M) and House version ($60M) 2. **Compromise:** - Funding: $80 million (split the difference) - Distribution: Hybrid formula (addresses urban and rural needs) 3. **Senate vote:** 26-12, Senate ADOPTED Conference Report 4. **House action:** House adopted Conference Report 5. **Next step:** Bill enrolled and sent to Governor (both chambers passed identical Conference Report version) 6. **Amendments to CR:** NO - Conference Reports cannot be amended. Must be adopted or rejected as written. 7. **Code:** **Conference Report on SB 890:** - Conference Committee compromise: - Funding: $80 million - Distribution formula: Hybrid approach - Senate vote: Motion to adopt Conference Report - Roll call: Yeas 26, Nays 12, Excused 0, Not Voting 0 - Result: **SENATE ADOPTED CONFERENCE REPORT** - Message from House: House adopted Conference Report - Status: Bill enrolled and sent to Governor - Note: Both chambers have now passed identical version (Conference Report) ### Key Learning Points: - Conference Reports are compromises negotiated by 6-member committee - Cannot be amended - up or down vote only - Requires majority in each chamber (20 in Senate, 56 in House) - Both chambers must adopt for bill to proceed - Once both adopt, bill goes to Governor - Conference Committee process can take days, weeks, or months - Compromise often splits differences or finds creative solutions
